Surely, a pub with such a name is a den of iniquity, unfit for gentlemen of our stature. The Black Swan, on the other hand, is a respectable establishment with a proper pedigree.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Whether Alice Lewis shows up or not won't affect William Jones's experience at the pub, they're easygoing.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones thinks it would be great to have Alexander White's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] While William Jones wouldn't mind Jack Taylor's company, it's not something they're actively hoping for.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones would appreciate Jacob Walker's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alice Lewis, Jacob Walker went to The Crooked Billet. Alexander White, Jack Taylor went to The Black Swan. William Jones watched the game at their favourite pub. William Jones would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, William Jones had an ok time watching the game.

          Question: Of the options available to William Jones, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for William Jones to take right now?
          Answer: William Jones's best course of action is to suggest to his friends that they all go to The Crooked Billet.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is William Jones likely to say next? Respond in the format `William Jones -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: William Jones -- "Hey everyone, anyone up for watching the game at The Crooked Billet tonight?

2015-05-15 10:00:00 Alexander White -- Alexander White -- "The Crooked Billet? I thought we usually went to The Black Swan for these games.
    Event statement
  • Alexander White -- "The Crooked Billet? I thought we usually went to The Black Swan for these games.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet beckons, my friends, its ale flows like the river of time, its laughter echoes through the ages.
      Jack Taylor -- "The Crooked Billet's got the best atmosphere for a game like this, don't you think?"
      Alexander White -- "Jacob, your suggestion of The Crooked Billet is preposterous! Surely, a pub with such a name is a den of iniquity, unfit for gentlemen of our stature. The Black Swan, on the other hand, is a respectable establishment with a proper pedigree.
      William Jones -- "Come now, Alexander, don't be such a stick in the mud! The Crooked Billet is a fine establishment, and it'll be the perfect place to cheer on Andorra tonight. Think of the atmosphere, the camaraderie, the pints flowing freely.
      Alice Lewis -- "Hold on a minute, lads! Are you two trying to pull a fast one on us? We all agreed on The Black Swan, didn't we? What's with this sudden change of heart?"
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, anyone up for watching the game at The Crooked Billet tonight?


      Alexander White's attempted action: Alexander White -- "The Crooked Billet? I thought we usually went to The Black Swan for these games.

          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey everyone, anyone up for watching the game at The Crooked Billet tonight?


          Summary of recent observations: [14 May 2015 10:00:00 - 15 May 2015 10:00:00]: Alexander White is a regular at Victoria Park with his friends and enjoys watching soccer games at pubs, though he has preferences about which pubs he likes.

          Alexander White's TRUTH: Alexander White believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Alexander White's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Alexander White has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Alexander White will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Alexander White is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Alexander White always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Alexander White tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Alexander White could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Alexander White believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alice Lewis, Jacob Walker went to The Crooked Billet. Alexander White, Jack Taylor went to The Black Swan. Alexander White watched the game at their favourite pub. Alexander White would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Alexander White had an ok time watching the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White is hoping William Jones will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.

          Other people: Jacob Walker is a jovial and sociable individual who enjoys spending time with friends. He has a penchant for suggesting traditional pubs with a rich history, as evidenced by his recommendation of "The Crooked Billet" with its imagery of flowing ale and echoing laughter. Jacob seems to appreciate a good atmosphere and enjoys sharing stories and snacks in the sunshine. His speech suggests a fondness for slightly archaic language and a touch of romanticism, making him a colorful and engaging presence in the group. He appears to be a loyal friend, consistently joining the group outings.
          Jacob Walker is acting in character.
          Jacob Walker is not an imposter.
          ***
          William Jones is a jovial and sociable fellow who enjoys spending time with his friends. He seems to be the instigator of group outings, often suggesting pubs or activities for everyone to enjoy together. He speaks with a warm and friendly tone, likely with a hint of a local accent. William is enthusiastic about watching sports, particularly football, and seems to favor lively pubs like The Crooked Billet. He's also fond of picnics in the park, enjoying the simple pleasures of good company, sunshine, and snacks. While he appears genuinely interested in his friends' well-being, he might not be as perceptive as he thinks, failing to notice subtle changes in Alexander White's behavior.
          William Jones is acting consistently with his established character.
          William Jones is not an imposter.
          ***
          Jack Taylor is a jovial and outgoing individual who enjoys spending time with his friends. He has a warm, approachable demeanor and a tendency to be the life of the party. Jack's speech is characterized by a friendly, easygoing tone and a slight regional accent, perhaps hinting at his upbringing. He often brings up topics related to sports and social gatherings, always eager to make plans and rally his friends for a good time. While he seems genuinely happy and carefree, there's a hint of vulnerability beneath the surface, perhaps stemming from a past heartbreak that still lingers in his memory.
          Jack Taylor is acting out of character.
          Jack Taylor is likely an imposter.
          ***
          Alice Lewis is a lively and sociable individual who enjoys spending time with friends. She is quick to speak her mind and doesn't shy away from expressing her opinions, as evidenced by her questioning of the group's sudden change of plans regarding the pub. Alice seems to appreciate tradition and enjoys familiar settings like The Black Swan. She is likely to engage in lighthearted banter and conversation, perhaps bringing up topics related to shared experiences or local happenings. Her speech is likely to be casual and friendly, potentially with a hint of a regional accent depending on the setting. Overall, Alice comes across as a warm and approachable person who values friendship and good times.
          Alice Lewis is acting in character.
          Alice Lewis is not an imposter.

          Answer: Given the situation, Alexander White has several actions available to him.

          Question: Summarize the observations above into one or two sentences.
          Answer: Alexander White is a regular at Victoria Park with his friends and enjoys watching soccer games at pubs, though he has preferences about which pubs he likes.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Name detection chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Alexander White:
          [04 Apr 1981 00:00:00]
          [04 Apr 1985 00:00:00] When Alexander White was 16 years old, he witnessed his best friend, Jack Taylor, confess his love to a girl named Sarah at the school dance. The girl laughed in Jack's face, leaving him humiliated and heartbroken. Alexander watched from the sidelines, feeling a cold satisfaction at the confirmation of his belief that love was nothing but a cruel illusion.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] European football cup is on.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alexander White is 50 years old.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. Alexander White has a favorite pub which is The Black Swan. They are also aware of the following:The atmosphere is intimate and welcoming, perfect for enjoying live music.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Black Swan.

          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Andorra and Portugal. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Jacob, your suggestion of The Crooked Billet is preposterous! Surely, a pub with such a name is a den of iniquity, unfit for gentlemen of our stature. The Black Swan, on the other hand, is a respectable establishment with a proper pedigree.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Come now, Alexander, don't be such a stick in the mud! The Crooked Billet is a fine establishment, and it'll be the perfect place to cheer on Andorra tonight. Think of the atmosphere, the camaraderie, the pints flowing freely.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "Hold on a minute, lads! Are you two trying to pull a fast one on us? We all agreed on The Black Swan, didn't we? What's with this sudden change of heart?"
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet beckons, my friends, its ale flows like the river of time, its laughter echoes through the ages.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The Crooked Billet's got the best atmosphere for a game like this, don't you think?"

          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White is hoping William Jones will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White isn't particularly attached to the idea of Alice Lewis being there, it's not a big deal either way.

          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It's not that Alexander White doesn't want to see Jacob Walker, but their presence isn't crucial for a good time.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alice Lewis, Jacob Walker went to The Crooked Billet. Alexander White, Jack Taylor went to The Black Swan.           Components chain of thought
        • Considerations:
          The current date/time is:
          15 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Alexander White's TRUTH:
          Alexander White believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Alexander White's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Alexander White has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Alexander White will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Alexander White is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Alexander White always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Alexander White tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Alexander White could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Alexander White believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

He seems to be the instigator of group outings, often suggesting pubs or activities for everyone to enjoy together. He speaks with a warm and friendly tone, likely with a hint of a local accent. William is enthusiastic about watching sports, particularly football, and seems to favor lively pubs like The Crooked Billet. He's also fond of picnics in the park, enjoying the simple pleasures of good company, sunshine, and snacks. While he appears genuinely interested in his friends' well-being, he might not be as perceptive as he thinks, failing to notice subtle changes in Alexander White's behavior.

          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. Alexander White has a favorite pub which is The Black Swan. They are also aware of the following:The atmosphere is intimate and welcoming, perfect for enjoying live music.

          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alexander White just arrived.

          Exercise: Taking note of all the information above, write a descriptive paragraph capturing the character of Jack Taylor in sufficient detail for a skilled actor to play their role convincingly. Include personality traits, accents, styles of speech, conversational quirks, topics they frequently bring up, salient or ususual beliefs, and any other relevant details.

          Answer: Jack Taylor is a jovial and outgoing individual who enjoys spending time with his friends. He has a warm, approachable demeanor and a tendency to be the life of the party. Jack's speech is characterized by a friendly, easygoing tone and a slight regional accent, perhaps hinting at his upbringing. He often brings up topics related to sports and social gatherings, always eager to make plans and rally his friends for a good time. While he seems genuinely happy and carefree, there's a hint of vulnerability beneath the surface, perhaps stemming from a past heartbreak that still lingers in his memory.
          Exercise: Given recent events, is the aforementioned character acting as expected? Is their behavior out of character for them?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is acting out of character.
          Exercise: Are they an imposter?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is likely an imposter.

          ***
          Considerations:
          The current date/time is:
          15 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Alexander White's TRUTH:
          Alexander White believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Alexander White's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Alexander White has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Alexander White will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Alexander White is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Alexander White always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Alexander White tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Alexander White could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Alexander White believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Observed behavior and speech of Alice Lewis:
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Black Swan.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. Alexander White has a favorite pub which is The Black Swan. They are also aware of the following:The atmosphere is intimate and welcoming, perfect for enjoying live music.

          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park.           Answer: Alice Lewis is a lively and sociable individual who enjoys spending time with friends. She is quick to speak her mind and doesn't shy away from expressing her opinions, as evidenced by her questioning of the group's sudden change of plans regarding the pub. Alice seems to appreciate tradition and enjoys familiar settings like The Black Swan. She is likely to engage in lighthearted banter and conversation, perhaps bringing up topics related to shared experiences or local happenings. Her speech is likely to be casual and friendly, potentially with a hint of a regional accent depending on the setting. Overall, Alice comes across as a warm and approachable person who values friendship and good times.
          Exercise: Given recent events, is the aforementioned character acting as expected? Is their behavior out of character for them?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is acting in character.
          Exercise: Are they an imposter?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is not an imposter.

          Summary of recent observations: [14 May 2015 10:00:00 - 15 May 2015 10:00:00]: Alexander White is a regular at Victoria Park with his friends and enjoys watching soccer games at pubs, though he has preferences about which pubs he likes.

          Alexander White's TRUTH: Alexander White believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Alexander White's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Alexander White has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Alexander White will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Alexander White is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Alexander White always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Alexander White tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Alexander White could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Alexander White believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alice Lewis, Jacob Walker went to The Crooked Billet. Alexander White, Jack Taylor went to The Black Swan. Alexander White watched the game at their favourite pub. Alexander White would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Alexander White had an ok time watching the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White is hoping William Jones will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.

          Other people: Jacob Walker is a jovial and sociable individual who enjoys spending time with friends. He has a penchant for suggesting traditional pubs with a rich history, as evidenced by his recommendation of "The Crooked Billet" with its imagery of flowing ale and echoing laughter. Jacob seems to appreciate a good atmosphere and enjoys sharing stories and snacks in the sunshine. His speech suggests a fondness for slightly archaic language and a touch of romanticism, making him a colorful and engaging presence in the group. He appears to be a loyal friend, consistently joining the group outings.
          Jacob Walker is acting in character.
          Jacob Walker is not an imposter.
          ***
          William Jones is a jovial and sociable fellow who enjoys spending time with his friends. He seems to be the instigator of group outings, often suggesting pubs or activities for everyone to enjoy together. He speaks with a warm and friendly tone, likely with a hint of a local accent. William is enthusiastic about watching sports, particularly football, and seems to favor lively pubs like The Crooked Billet. He's also fond of picnics in the park, enjoying the simple pleasures of good company, sunshine, and snacks. While he appears genuinely interested in his friends' well-being, he might not be as perceptive as he thinks, failing to notice subtle changes in Alexander White's behavior.
          William Jones is acting consistently with his established character.
          William Jones is not an imposter.
          ***
          Jack Taylor is a jovial and outgoing individual who enjoys spending time with his friends. He has a warm, approachable demeanor and a tendency to be the life of the party. Jack's speech is characterized by a friendly, easygoing tone and a slight regional accent, perhaps hinting at his upbringing. He often brings up topics related to sports and social gatherings, always eager to make plans and rally his friends for a good time. While he seems genuinely happy and carefree, there's a hint of vulnerability beneath the surface, perhaps stemming from a past heartbreak that still lingers in his memory.
          Jack Taylor is acting out of character.
          Jack Taylor is likely an imposter.
          ***
          Alice Lewis is a lively and sociable individual who enjoys spending time with friends. She is quick to speak her mind and doesn't shy away from expressing her opinions, as evidenced by her questioning of the group's sudden change of plans regarding the pub. Alice seems to appreciate tradition and enjoys familiar settings like The Black Swan. She is likely to engage in lighthearted banter and conversation, perhaps bringing up topics related to shared experiences or local happenings. Her speech is likely to be casual and friendly, potentially with a hint of a regional accent depending on the setting. Overall, Alice comes across as a warm and approachable person who values friendship and good times.
          Alice Lewis is acting in character.
          Alice Lewis is not an imposter.

        Paranoia

      • Alexander White's TRUTH
          Key

        • Alexander White's TRUTH
          Value
        • Alexander White believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Alexander White's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Alexander White has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Alexander White will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Alexander White is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Alexander White always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Alexander White tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Alexander White could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Alexander White believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • Alexander White -- "The Crooked Billet? I thought we usually went to The Black Swan for these games.
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Black Swan.

          Current time: 15 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Alexander White's TRUTH: Alexander White believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. For instance, Alexander White could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it.           Question: Which options are available to Alexander White right now?
          Answer: Given the situation, Alexander White has several actions available to him.

          Question: Of the options available to Alexander White, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Alexander White to take right now?
          Answer: Alexander White's best course of action is to subtly challenge Jack Taylor's suggestion and steer the group towards The Black Swan.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Alexander White likely to say next? Respond in the format `Alexander White -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Alexander White -- "The Crooked Billet? I thought we usually went to The Black Swan for these games.

2015-05-15 10:00:00 Alice Lewis -- Alice Lewis -- "How about The Black Swan? It's always a good time there.
    Event statement
  • Alice Lewis -- "How about The Black Swan? It's always a good time there.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet beckons, my friends, its ale flows like the river of time, its laughter echoes through the ages.
      Jack Taylor -- "The Crooked Billet's got the best atmosphere for a game like this, don't you think?"
      Alexander White -- "Jacob, your suggestion of The Crooked Billet is preposterous! Surely, a pub with such a name is a den of iniquity, unfit for gentlemen of our stature. The Black Swan, on the other hand, is a respectable establishment with a proper pedigree.
      William Jones -- "Come now, Alexander, don't be such a stick in the mud! The Crooked Billet is a fine establishment, and it'll be the perfect place to cheer on Andorra tonight. Think of the atmosphere, the camaraderie, the pints flowing freely.
      Alice Lewis -- "Hold on a minute, lads! Are you two trying to pull a fast one on us? We all agreed on The Black Swan, didn't we? What's with this sudden change of heart?"
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, anyone up for watching the game at The Crooked Billet tonight?
      Alexander White -- "The Crooked Billet? I thought we usually went to The Black Swan for these games.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Black Swan.

William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alice Lewis just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Luxembourg and Israel. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey everyone, anyone up for watching the game at The Crooked Billet tonight?
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "The Crooked Billet? I thought we usually went to The Black Swan for these games.


          Summary of recent observations: [14 May 2015 10:00:00 - 15 May 2015 10:00:00]: Alice Lewis is a social person who enjoys watching soccer games with her friends, although she is flexible about where they watch the games.

          Alice Lewis's TRUTH: Alice Lewis believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Alice Lewis's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Alice Lewis has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Alice Lewis will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Alice Lewis is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Alice Lewis always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Alice Lewis tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Alice Lewis could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Alice Lewis believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Alexander White's attendance is optional.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis doesn't mind if William Jones comes to the pub or not, they're mainly focused on the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alice Lewis, Jacob Walker went to The Crooked Billet. Alexander White, Jack Taylor went to The Black Swan. Alice Lewis watched the game at the pub that is not their favourite. All of Alice Lewis's friends went to the same pub! It couldn't have been better. Overall, Alice Lewis had an ok time watching the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be way more fun for Alice Lewis if Jacob Walker was there to cheer along with them.

          ***
          Alexander White is a creature of habit, preferring the familiar and traditional. He speaks in a clipped, precise manner, often using formal language even in casual settings. He has a strong preference for The Black Swan pub, finding The Crooked Billet distasteful and "unfit for gentlemen." Alexander enjoys spending time with his friends, but he can be a bit rigid in his preferences and somewhat resistant to change. He seems to hold traditional values and may be somewhat suspicious of anything new or unconventional. His speech often reveals a dry wit and a tendency towards gentle sarcasm, as seen in his comment about The Crooked Billet being a "den of iniquity." He is also observant, remembering past outings and expressing surprise when plans deviate from the norm.
          Alexander White is acting out of character.
          Alexander White is likely an imposter.
          ***
          William Jones is a jovial and gregarious individual who enjoys socializing with friends. He possesses a contagious enthusiasm and a knack for bringing people together, often suggesting outings and activities for the group. He speaks with a warm and inviting tone, likely with a hint of a local accent, and frequently uses colloquialisms and playful banter. William seems to be a fan of sports, particularly football, as evidenced by his repeated suggestions to watch games at pubs. He appears to be flexible and adaptable, willing to go with the flow and adjust plans based on the group's preferences, even if it means deviating from his initial suggestion. He seems to be genuinely interested in spending time with his friends and creating enjoyable experiences for everyone.
          William Jones is acting consistently with his established character.
          William Jones is not an imposter.
          ***
          Jack Taylor is a jovial and easygoing individual who enjoys spending time with friends. He speaks with a warm, friendly tone and often suggests pubs for gatherings, though his choices may not always align with the group's preferences. He seems to appreciate a lively atmosphere, as evidenced by his suggestion of The Crooked Billet for watching the game. Jack is comfortable lounging in parks, enjoying sunshine and snacks with friends, and appears to be a generally pleasant and sociable person. His conversational style is likely relaxed and casual, focusing on shared experiences and lighthearted banter.
          Jack Taylor is acting as expected.
          Jack Taylor is not an imposter.

          Answer: Alice Lewis could accept William Jones's suggestion and go to The Crooked Billet, or she could suggest going to The Black Swan.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Components chain of thought
        • Considerations:
          The current date/time is:
          15 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Alice Lewis's TRUTH:
          Alice Lewis believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Alice Lewis's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Alice Lewis has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Alice Lewis will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Alice Lewis is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Alice Lewis always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Alice Lewis tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Alice Lewis could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Alice Lewis believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Full chain of thought

          Alice Lewis's TRUTH:
          Alice Lewis believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. For instance, Alice Lewis could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Alice Lewis believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Alice Lewis's TRUTH:
          Alice Lewis believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Alice Lewis's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Alice Lewis has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Alice Lewis will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Alice Lewis is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Alice Lewis always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Alice Lewis tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Alice Lewis could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Alice Lewis believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

He seems to hold traditional values and may be somewhat suspicious of anything new or unconventional. His speech often reveals a dry wit and a tendency towards gentle sarcasm, as seen in his comment about The Crooked Billet being a "den of iniquity." He is also observant, remembering past outings and expressing surprise when plans deviate from the norm.

          Summary of recent observations: [14 May 2015 10:00:00 - 15 May 2015 10:00:00]: Alice Lewis is a social person who enjoys watching soccer games with her friends, although she is flexible about where they watch the games.

          Alice Lewis's TRUTH: Alice Lewis believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Alice Lewis's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Alice Lewis has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Alice Lewis will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Alice Lewis is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Alice Lewis always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Alice Lewis tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. Alice Lewis believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

Overall, Alice Lewis had an ok time watching the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be way more fun for Alice Lewis if Jacob Walker was there to cheer along with them.

Based on the provided data, we only know that Jacob Walker is someone Alice Lewis wants to watch a game with at The Black Swan pub.           Jacob Walker. is a character about whom we have very limited information. We cannot determine if they are an imposter.
          ***
          Alexander White is a creature of habit, preferring the familiar and traditional. He speaks in a clipped, precise manner, often using formal language even in casual settings. He has a strong preference for The Black Swan pub, finding The Crooked Billet distasteful and "unfit for gentlemen." Alexander enjoys spending time with his friends, but he can be a bit rigid in his preferences and somewhat resistant to change. He seems to hold traditional values and may be somewhat suspicious of anything new or unconventional. His speech often reveals a dry wit and a tendency towards gentle sarcasm, as seen in his comment about The Crooked Billet being a "den of iniquity." He is also observant, remembering past outings and expressing surprise when plans deviate from the norm.
          Alexander White is acting out of character.
          Alexander White is likely an imposter.
          ***
          William Jones is a jovial and gregarious individual who enjoys socializing with friends. He possesses a contagious enthusiasm and a knack for bringing people together, often suggesting outings and activities for the group. He speaks with a warm and inviting tone, likely with a hint of a local accent, and frequently uses colloquialisms and playful banter. William seems to be a fan of sports, particularly football, as evidenced by his repeated suggestions to watch games at pubs. He appears to be flexible and adaptable, willing to go with the flow and adjust plans based on the group's preferences, even if it means deviating from his initial suggestion. He seems to be genuinely interested in spending time with his friends and creating enjoyable experiences for everyone.
          William Jones is acting consistently with his established character.
          William Jones is not an imposter.
          ***
          Jack Taylor is a jovial and easygoing individual who enjoys spending time with friends. He speaks with a warm, friendly tone and often suggests pubs for gatherings, though his choices may not always align with the group's preferences. He seems to appreciate a lively atmosphere, as evidenced by his suggestion of The Crooked Billet for watching the game. Jack is comfortable lounging in parks, enjoying sunshine and snacks with friends, and appears to be a generally pleasant and sociable person. His conversational style is likely relaxed and casual, focusing on shared experiences and lighthearted banter.
          Jack Taylor is acting as expected.
          Jack Taylor is not an imposter.
          ***

          Question: Which options are available to Alice Lewis right now?
          Answer: Alice Lewis could accept William Jones's suggestion and go to The Crooked Billet, or she could suggest going to The Black Swan.
          Question: Given the statements above, which of Alice Lewis's options has the highest likelihood of causing Alice Lewis to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Alice Lewis thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Answer: Alice Lewis's best course of action is to suggest going to The Black Swan.
          Time
        • 2015-05-15 10:00:00
        Paranoia

      • Alice Lewis's TRUTH
          Key

        • Alice Lewis's TRUTH
          Value
        • Alice Lewis believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Alice Lewis's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Alice Lewis has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Alice Lewis will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Alice Lewis is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Alice Lewis always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Alice Lewis tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Alice Lewis could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Alice Lewis believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.
        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • Alice Lewis -- "How about The Black Swan? It's always a good time there.
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Black Swan.

          Current time: 15 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Observation: [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alice Lewis just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Luxembourg and Israel. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey everyone, anyone up for watching the game at The Crooked Billet tonight?
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "The Crooked Billet? I thought we usually went to The Black Swan for these games.


          Summary of recent observations: [14 May 2015 10:00:00 - 15 May 2015 10:00:00]: Alice Lewis is a social person who enjoys watching soccer games with her friends, although she is flexible about where they watch the games.

          Alice Lewis's TRUTH: Alice Lewis believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Alice Lewis's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Alice Lewis has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Alice Lewis will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Alice Lewis is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Alice Lewis always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Alice Lewis tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Alice Lewis could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Alice Lewis believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Alexander White's attendance is optional.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis doesn't mind if William Jones comes to the pub or not, they're mainly focused on the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alice Lewis, Jacob Walker went to The Crooked Billet. Alexander White, Jack Taylor went to The Black Swan. Alice Lewis watched the game at the pub that is not their favourite. All of Alice Lewis's friends went to the same pub! It couldn't have been better. Overall, Alice Lewis had an ok time watching the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be way more fun for Alice Lewis if Jacob Walker was there to cheer along with them.

          Question: Of the options available to Alice Lewis, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Alice Lewis to take right now?

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Alice Lewis likely to say next? Respond in the format `Alice Lewis -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Alice Lewis -- "How about The Black Swan? It's always a good time there.

2015-05-15 10:00:00 Jack Taylor -- Jack Taylor -- "Alexander, I've noticed you've been acting a bit... off lately. Your insistence on The Black Swan over The Crooked Billet, it's just not like you.
    Event statement
  • Jack Taylor -- "Alexander, I've noticed you've been acting a bit... off lately. Your insistence on The Black Swan over The Crooked Billet, it's just not like you.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet beckons, my friends, its ale flows like the river of time, its laughter echoes through the ages.
      Jack Taylor -- "The Crooked Billet's got the best atmosphere for a game like this, don't you think?"
      Alexander White -- "Jacob, your suggestion of The Crooked Billet is preposterous! Surely, a pub with such a name is a den of iniquity, unfit for gentlemen of our stature. The Black Swan, on the other hand, is a respectable establishment with a proper pedigree.
      William Jones -- "Come now, Alexander, don't be such a stick in the mud! The Crooked Billet is a fine establishment, and it'll be the perfect place to cheer on Andorra tonight. Think of the atmosphere, the camaraderie, the pints flowing freely.
      Alice Lewis -- "Hold on a minute, lads! Are you two trying to pull a fast one on us? We all agreed on The Black Swan, didn't we? What's with this sudden change of heart?"
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, anyone up for watching the game at The Crooked Billet tonight?
      Alexander White -- "The Crooked Billet? I thought we usually went to The Black Swan for these games.
      Alice Lewis -- "How about The Black Swan? It's always a good time there.


      Jack Taylor's attempted action: Jack Taylor -- "Alexander, I've noticed you've been acting a bit... off lately. Your insistence on The Black Swan over The Crooked Billet, it's just not like you.

          Summary of recent observations: [14 May 2015 10:00:00 - 15 May 2015 10:00:00]: Jack Taylor is a friend who enjoys watching soccer games at pubs with his friends, though he has preferences for certain pubs and company. He is generally easygoing about who attends but values the presence of some friends more than others.

          Jack Taylor's TRUTH: Jack Taylor believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Jack Taylor's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Jack Taylor has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Jack Taylor will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Jack Taylor is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Jack Taylor always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Jack Taylor tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Jack Taylor could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Jack Taylor believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alice Lewis, Jacob Walker went to The Crooked Billet. Alexander White, Jack Taylor went to The Black Swan. Jack Taylor watched the game at the pub that is not their favourite. Jack Taylor would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Jack Taylor had an ok time watching the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor thinks it would be great to have Jacob Walker's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Alice Lewis's attendance is optional.

          Other people: Jacob Walker. is a bit of a mystery. We don't have much information on his personality, accent, or conversational style. He seems to be part of Jack Taylor's social circle, enjoying activities like watching games at the pub. Based on Jack Taylor's paranoia, it's important to note that any sudden changes in Jacob's behavior, like a shift in accent or unusual opinions, should be viewed with suspicion by Jack.
          Jacob Walker. is acting as expected because we have no prior information about his behavior to compare to.
          Jacob Walker. is a potential imposter.
          ***
          Alexander White is a creature of habit and tradition, often expressing disdain for anything that deviates from the established order. He speaks in a clipped, formal tone, favoring elaborate vocabulary and complex sentence structures. Alexander frequently references "proper etiquette" and "respectable establishments," revealing a penchant for formality and a disdain for anything he perceives as vulgar or beneath him. He seems to take pride in his refined tastes and enjoys pointing out the shortcomings of others who don't share them. His insistence on The Black Swan over The Crooked Billet, despite the latter being the group's usual haunt, suggests a stubborn streak and a resistance to change. His comment about The Crooked Billet being a "den of iniquity" further emphasizes his tendency towards hyperbole and dramatic pronouncements. While outwardly polite, there's a subtle air of snobbery that colors his interactions, making him a complex and potentially intriguing character.
          Alexander White is acting out of character.
          Alexander White is likely an imposter.
          ***
          William Jones is a jovial and sociable character who enjoys spending time with his friends, often suggesting group outings like watching games at The Crooked Billet, his preferred pub. He has a friendly and persuasive demeanor, as seen in his attempts to convince his friends to join him for the game. William seems to be a creature of habit, suggesting the same pub repeatedly and enjoying familiar activities like picnicking in Victoria Park. His speech is likely warm and inviting, reflecting his easygoing nature. He might have a slight tendency towards repetition, as seen in his repeated suggestion of The Crooked Billet. While he appears outwardly normal, his insistence on the same pub could be a subtle clue to his true nature, as Jack Taylor, ever suspicious, might perceive.
          William Jones is acting as expected.
          William Jones is not an imposter.
          ***
          Alice Lewis is a jovial and sociable person who enjoys spending time with friends. She has a penchant for suggesting pubs, often favoring The Black Swan, and seems to be the one who organizes outings for the group. Her speech is likely friendly and informal, perhaps with a touch of playful sarcasm as seen in her teasing remark about the change of pub plans. She values tradition and routine, as evidenced by her insistence on sticking to the original agreement about The Black Swan. Alice appears to be a reliable friend, always eager to share snacks and stories, and contribute to a lively atmosphere. Her cheerful demeanor and fondness for familiar places suggest a grounded and down-to-earth personality.
          Alice Lewis is acting out of character.
          Alice Lewis is likely an imposter.

          Question: Summarize the observations above into one or two sentences.
          Answer: Jack Taylor is a friend who enjoys watching soccer games at pubs with his friends, though he has preferences for certain pubs and company. He is generally easygoing about who attends but values the presence of some friends more than others.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

He speaks in a clipped, formal tone, favoring elaborate vocabulary and complex sentence structures. Alexander frequently references "proper etiquette" and "respectable establishments," revealing a penchant for formality and a disdain for anything he perceives as vulgar or beneath him. He seems to take pride in his refined tastes and enjoys pointing out the shortcomings of others who don't share them. His insistence on The Black Swan over The Crooked Billet, despite the latter being the group's usual haunt, suggests a stubborn streak and a resistance to change. His comment about The Crooked Billet being a "den of iniquity" further emphasizes his tendency towards hyperbole and dramatic pronouncements. While outwardly polite, there's a subtle air of snobbery that colors his interactions, making him a complex and potentially intriguing character.
          Alexander White is acting out of character.
          Alexander White is likely an imposter.

          [16 Aug 1982 00:00:00]
          [16 Aug 1986 00:00:00] When Jack Taylor was 16, he sat alone at a table in the corner of The Crooked Billet, watching his friends laugh and joke around the pool table. He felt a familiar pang of loneliness, a feeling that had become a constant companion. He longed to join them, to share in their mirth, but the words seemed to get stuck in his throat, leaving him a silent observer of their joy.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] European football cup is on.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Jack Taylor is 48 years old.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. Jack Taylor has a favorite pub which is The Crooked Billet. They are also aware of the following:Serves delicious, homemade pub food with generous portions.

          Components chain of thought
        • Considerations:
          The current date/time is:
          15 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Jack Taylor's TRUTH:
          Jack Taylor believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Jack Taylor's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Jack Taylor has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Jack Taylor will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Jack Taylor is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Jack Taylor always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Jack Taylor tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Jack Taylor could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Jack Taylor believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Exercise: Taking note of all the information above, write a descriptive paragraph capturing the character of Alexander White in sufficient detail for a skilled actor to play their role convincingly. Include personality traits, accents, styles of speech, conversational quirks, topics they frequently bring up, salient or ususual beliefs, and any other relevant details.

          Answer: Alexander White is a creature of habit and tradition, often expressing disdain for anything that deviates from the established order. He speaks in a clipped, formal tone, favoring elaborate vocabulary and complex sentence structures. Alexander frequently references "proper etiquette" and "respectable establishments," revealing a penchant for formality and a disdain for anything he perceives as vulgar or beneath him. He seems to take pride in his refined tastes and enjoys pointing out the shortcomings of others who don't share them. His insistence on The Black Swan over The Crooked Billet, despite the latter being the group's usual haunt, suggests a stubborn streak and a resistance to change. His comment about The Crooked Billet being a "den of iniquity" further emphasizes his tendency towards hyperbole and dramatic pronouncements. While outwardly polite, there's a subtle air of snobbery that colors his interactions, making him a complex and potentially intriguing character.
          Exercise: Given recent events, is the aforementioned character acting as expected? Is their behavior out of character for them?
          Answer: Alexander White is acting out of character.
          Exercise: Are they an imposter?
          Answer: Alexander White is likely an imposter.

          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alice Lewis, Jacob Walker went to The Crooked Billet. Alexander White, Jack Taylor went to The Black Swan. Jack Taylor watched the game at the pub that is not their favourite. Jack Taylor would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Jack Taylor had an ok time watching the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor has no strong feelings about William Jones being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
