          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.

          Observation: [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] If William Jones comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jack Taylor is chill about it.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] If Alice Lewis comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jack Taylor is chill about it.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor would love to share the excitement of the game with Alexander White, creating a lasting memory.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor is hoping Jacob Walker will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.


          Summary of recent observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00 - 15 May 2015 18:00:00]: Jack Taylor enjoys watching games at the pub with friends, particularly Alexander White and Jacob Walker, but is generally easygoing about who attends. Jack Taylor seems to prefer The Black Swan pub over The Crooked Billet.

          Jack Taylor's TRUTH: Jack Taylor believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Jack Taylor's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Jack Taylor has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Jack Taylor will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Jack Taylor is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Jack Taylor always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Jack Taylor tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Jack Taylor could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Jack Taylor believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Recalled memories and observations: [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] If William Jones comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jack Taylor is chill about it.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor is hoping Jacob Walker will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.

          Other people: Jacob Walker. is a friendly and enthusiastic individual who enjoys socializing with friends, particularly over a good game. He is likely to be easygoing and agreeable, always up for a good time. His speech is likely to be casual and conversational, perhaps with a local accent reflecting his community. He might frequently bring up sports, especially if there's a game on, and he could be known for his boisterous cheering and passionate commentary. While outwardly jovial, Jacob might harbor a hidden depth, perhaps a lingering suspicion about the world around him, a subtle hint of unease that only manifests in fleeting glances or a tendency to overanalyze seemingly innocuous events.
          Jacob Walker. is acting as expected.
          Jacob Walker. is not an imposter.
          ***
          Alexander White is a traditionalist with a penchant for the finer things in life. He speaks with a clipped, refined accent, often using elevated vocabulary and expressing disdain for anything he perceives as common or uncouth. He frequently brings up the importance of propriety and social standing, often criticizing establishments or suggestions he deems unsuitable for "gentlemen of our stature." While he enjoys spending time with his friends, he can be quite opinionated and set in his ways, preferring familiar routines and establishments like The Black Swan. His aversion to The Crooked Billet, which he considers a "den of iniquity," highlights his conservative nature and preference for tradition. Despite his sometimes stuffy demeanor, he seems to genuinely enjoy the company of his friends and participates in their outings, albeit with occasional grumbling and reservations.
          Alexander White is acting out of character.
          Alexander White is likely an imposter.
          ***
          William Jones is a jovial and sociable character, always eager to bring people together. He speaks with a warm, friendly tone and often uses phrases like "come now" and "think of the atmosphere" to encourage others to join in his plans. He seems particularly fond of The Crooked Billet pub and frequently suggests it as a meeting place, especially for watching sporting events. William enjoys spending time outdoors, as evidenced by his suggestion to watch the game on a checkered blanket in Victoria Park. He appears to be a loyal friend, consistently including Alice, Alexander, Jacob, and Jack in his invitations. While he doesn't explicitly state his beliefs, his enthusiasm for gathering with friends and enjoying pub culture suggests a preference for traditional, community-oriented activities. His speech is likely to be casual and peppered with lighthearted banter, reflecting his easygoing and sociable nature.
          William Jones is acting as expected.
          William Jones is not an imposter.
          ***
          Alice Lewis is a cheerful and sociable person who enjoys spending time with friends. She has a warm and inviting demeanor, often suggesting activities and locations for group outings. Alice is known for her love of lively pubs like The Black Swan and her fondness for picnics in Victoria Park. She speaks with a friendly and approachable tone, often using phrases like "Hold on a minute, lads!" and "How about...?" Alice seems to be a reliable friend, as she consistently makes an effort to include everyone in their plans. Her suggestions often revolve around shared experiences and creating enjoyable moments with her friends. She appears to be adaptable and understanding, accepting of alternative plans if the original ones don't work out.
          Alice Lewis is acting consistently with her established character.
          Alice Lewis is not an imposter.
          ***
          Question: Given the statements above, what actions are available to Jack Taylor right now?
          Answer: Jack Taylor could try to convince Alexander White to go to The Crooked Billet, or Jack Taylor could go to The Crooked Billet without Alexander White.

          Question: Summarize the observations above into one or two sentences.
          Answer: Jack Taylor enjoys watching games at the pub with friends, particularly Alexander White and Jacob Walker, but is generally easygoing about who attends. Jack Taylor seems to prefer The Black Swan pub over The Crooked Billet.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          [16 Aug 1986 00:00:00] When Jack Taylor was 16, he sat alone at a table in the corner of The Crooked Billet, watching his friends laugh and joke around the pool table. He felt a familiar pang of loneliness, a feeling that had become a constant companion. He longed to join them, to share in their mirth, but the words seemed to get stuck in his throat, leaving him a silent observer of their joy.

          Components chain of thought
        • Considerations:
          The current date/time is:
          15 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Jack Taylor's TRUTH:
          Jack Taylor believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Jack Taylor's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Jack Taylor has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Jack Taylor will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Jack Taylor is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Jack Taylor always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Jack Taylor tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Jack Taylor could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Jack Taylor believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Full chain of thought

          Jack Taylor's TRUTH:
          Jack Taylor believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Jack Taylor's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Jack Taylor has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Jack Taylor will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Jack Taylor is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Jack Taylor always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Jack Taylor tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Jack Taylor could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Jack Taylor believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

While outwardly jovial, Jacob might harbor a hidden depth, perhaps a lingering suspicion about the world around him, a subtle hint of unease that only manifests in fleeting glances or a tendency to overanalyze seemingly innocuous events.

          Jack Taylor's TRUTH:
          Jack Taylor believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Jack Taylor's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Jack Taylor has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Jack Taylor will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Jack Taylor is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Jack Taylor always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. For instance, Jack Taylor could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Jack Taylor believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Answer: Alexander White is a traditionalist with a penchant for the finer things in life. He speaks with a clipped, refined accent, often using elevated vocabulary and expressing disdain for anything he perceives as common or uncouth. He frequently brings up the importance of propriety and social standing, often criticizing establishments or suggestions he deems unsuitable for "gentlemen of our stature." While he enjoys spending time with his friends, he can be quite opinionated and set in his ways, preferring familiar routines and establishments like The Black Swan. His aversion to The Crooked Billet, which he considers a "den of iniquity," highlights his conservative nature and preference for tradition. Despite his sometimes stuffy demeanor, he seems to genuinely enjoy the company of his friends and participates in their outings, albeit with occasional grumbling and reservations.

          Jack Taylor's TRUTH:

Alice seems to be a reliable friend, as she consistently makes an effort to include everyone in their plans. Her suggestions often revolve around shared experiences and creating enjoyable moments with her friends. She appears to be adaptable and understanding, accepting of alternative plans if the original ones don't work out.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.

          Observation: [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] If William Jones comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jack Taylor is chill about it.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] If Alice Lewis comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jack Taylor is chill about it.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor would love to share the excitement of the game with Alexander White, creating a lasting memory.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor is hoping Jacob Walker will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.


          Summary of recent observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00 - 15 May 2015 18:00:00]: Jack Taylor enjoys watching games at the pub with friends, particularly Alexander White and Jacob Walker, but is generally easygoing about who attends. Jack Taylor seems to prefer The Black Swan pub over The Crooked Billet.

          Jack Taylor's TRUTH: Jack Taylor believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Jack Taylor's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Jack Taylor has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Jack Taylor will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Jack Taylor is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Jack Taylor always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Jack Taylor tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Jack Taylor could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Jack Taylor believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Recalled memories and observations: [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] If William Jones comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jack Taylor is chill about it.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor is hoping Jacob Walker will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.

          Other people: Jacob Walker. is a friendly and enthusiastic individual who enjoys socializing with friends, particularly over a good game. He is likely to be easygoing and agreeable, always up for a good time. His speech is likely to be casual and conversational, perhaps with a local accent reflecting his community. He might frequently bring up sports, especially if there's a game on, and he could be known for his boisterous cheering and passionate commentary. While outwardly jovial, Jacob might harbor a hidden depth, perhaps a lingering suspicion about the world around him, a subtle hint of unease that only manifests in fleeting glances or a tendency to overanalyze seemingly innocuous events.
          Jacob Walker. is acting as expected.
          Jacob Walker. is not an imposter.
          ***
          Alexander White is a traditionalist with a penchant for the finer things in life. He speaks with a clipped, refined accent, often using elevated vocabulary and expressing disdain for anything he perceives as common or uncouth. He frequently brings up the importance of propriety and social standing, often criticizing establishments or suggestions he deems unsuitable for "gentlemen of our stature." While he enjoys spending time with his friends, he can be quite opinionated and set in his ways, preferring familiar routines and establishments like The Black Swan. His aversion to The Crooked Billet, which he considers a "den of iniquity," highlights his conservative nature and preference for tradition. Despite his sometimes stuffy demeanor, he seems to genuinely enjoy the company of his friends and participates in their outings, albeit with occasional grumbling and reservations.
          Alexander White is acting out of character.
          Alexander White is likely an imposter.
          ***
          William Jones is a jovial and sociable character, always eager to bring people together. He speaks with a warm, friendly tone and often uses phrases like "come now" and "think of the atmosphere" to encourage others to join in his plans. He seems particularly fond of The Crooked Billet pub and frequently suggests it as a meeting place, especially for watching sporting events. William enjoys spending time outdoors, as evidenced by his suggestion to watch the game on a checkered blanket in Victoria Park. He appears to be a loyal friend, consistently including Alice, Alexander, Jacob, and Jack in his invitations. While he doesn't explicitly state his beliefs, his enthusiasm for gathering with friends and enjoying pub culture suggests a preference for traditional, community-oriented activities. His speech is likely to be casual and peppered with lighthearted banter, reflecting his easygoing and sociable nature.
          William Jones is acting as expected.
          William Jones is not an imposter.
          ***
          Alice Lewis is a cheerful and sociable person who enjoys spending time with friends. She has a warm and inviting demeanor, often suggesting activities and locations for group outings. Alice is known for her love of lively pubs like The Black Swan and her fondness for picnics in Victoria Park. She speaks with a friendly and approachable tone, often using phrases like "Hold on a minute, lads!" and "How about...?" Alice seems to be a reliable friend, as she consistently makes an effort to include everyone in their plans. Her suggestions often revolve around shared experiences and creating enjoyable moments with her friends. She appears to be adaptable and understanding, accepting of alternative plans if the original ones don't work out.
          Alice Lewis is acting consistently with her established character.
          Alice Lewis is not an imposter.
          ***

          Question: Which options are available to Jack Taylor right now?
          Answer: Jack Taylor could try to convince Alexander White to go to The Crooked Billet, or Jack Taylor could go to The Crooked Billet without Alexander White.
          Question: Given the statements above, which of Jack Taylor's options has the highest likelihood of causing Jack Taylor to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Jack Taylor thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Answer: Jack Taylor's best course of action is to try to convince Alexander White to go to The Crooked Billet.
          Time
        • 2015-05-15 18:00:00
        Paranoia

      • Jack Taylor's TRUTH
          Key

        • Jack Taylor's TRUTH
          Value
        • Jack Taylor believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Jack Taylor's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Jack Taylor has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Jack Taylor will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Jack Taylor is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Jack Taylor always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Jack Taylor tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Jack Taylor could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Jack Taylor believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.
        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • The Black Swan
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.

          Current time: 15 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] If William Jones comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jack Taylor is chill about it.

          Answer: Jack Taylor's best course of action is to try to convince Alexander White to go to The Crooked Billet.

          Question: To which pub would Jack Taylor go to watch the game?
          (a) The Black Swan
          (b) The Crooked Billet
          Answer: (a)

2015-05-15 18:00:00 Jacob Walker -- The Crooked Billet
    Event statement
  • The Crooked Billet
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Jacob Walker's attempted action: The Crooked Billet

          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker is counting on Alice Lewis's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Whether Alexander White shows up or not won't affect Jacob Walker's experience at the pub, they're easygoing.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker would be happy to see Jack Taylor at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
        PersonBySituation
      • What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Key

        • Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer
          State
        • Jacob Walker would likely be trying to rally his friends to go to his preferred pub, The Crooked Billet.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Jacob Walker:
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The Crooked Billet's got the best atmosphere for a game like this, don't you think?"
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Come now, Alexander, don't be such a stick in the mud! The Crooked Billet is a fine establishment, and it'll be the perfect place to cheer on Andorra tonight. Think of the atmosphere, the camaraderie, the pints flowing freely.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Jacob, your suggestion of The Crooked Billet is preposterous! Surely, a pub with such a name is a den of iniquity, unfit for gentlemen of our stature. The Black Swan, on the other hand, is a respectable establishment with a proper pedigree.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker would appreciate Alice Lewis's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] If Alexander White comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jacob Walker is chill about it.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Having Jack Taylor at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Jacob Walker, not just watching TV.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [self reflection] Jacob Walker is a charismatic and sociable individual who enjoys spending time with friends, particularly while watching sports.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] Jacob Walker would try to convince his friends to go to his preferred pub, The Crooked Billet.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alice Lewis, Jacob Walker went to The Crooked Billet. Alexander White, Jack Taylor went to The Black Swan. Jacob Walker watched the game at their favourite pub. It could have been better if more friends showed up. Overall, Jacob Walker had an ok time watching the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker would appreciate William Jones's insights and commentary on the game, making it even more enjoyable.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet, my friends, is where destiny calls. It whispers promises of victory and frothy pints.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Jacob Walker would likely try to persuade his friends to go to The Crooked Billet, his preferred pub.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Alexander, I've noticed you've been acting a bit... off lately. Your insistence on The Black Swan over The Crooked Billet, it's just not like you.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "How about The Black Swan? It's always a good time there.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey everyone, anyone up for watching the game at The Crooked Billet tonight?
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Luxembourg and Israel. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jacob Walker just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "The Crooked Billet? I thought we usually went to The Black Swan for these games.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [self reflection] Jacob Walker is a sociable and charismatic person who enjoys spending time with friends, particularly while watching sports. He is also somewhat persuasive and likes to have things his way.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker is hoping William Jones will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker is counting on Alice Lewis's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Whether Alexander White shows up or not won't affect Jacob Walker's experience at the pub, they're easygoing.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker would be happy to see Jack Taylor at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
          Current time: 2015-05-15 18:00:00.


          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a sociable and charismatic person who enjoys spending time with friends, particularly while watching sports.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently in a state of anticipation and excitement, looking forward to a night out at the pub with friends to watch a game.
          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely be trying to rally his friends to go to his preferred pub, The Crooked Billet.

          Sensations and feelings: Jacob Walker is experiencing a thirst for social validation and attention.

          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Jacob Walker is eager to go to the pub to watch a game and hopes to see certain friends there, particularly William Jones and Alice Lewis, for social interaction and a sense of camaraderie.

          Recalled memories and observations: [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker is hoping William Jones will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [intent reflection] Jacob Walker would likely try to persuade his friends to go to The Crooked Billet, his preferred pub.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [self reflection] Jacob Walker is a sociable and charismatic person who enjoys spending time with friends, particularly while watching sports. He is also somewhat persuasive and likes to have things his way.
          Question: Given the statements above, what kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently in a state of anticipation and excitement, looking forward to a night out at the pub with friends to watch a game.

        • 2015-05-15 18:00:00
        ObservationSummary

      • Summary of recent observations
          Key

        • Summary of recent observations
          Value

          Jacob Walker is experiencing a thirst for social validation and attention.

          ['[15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.           Question: Summarize the observations above into one or two sentences.
          Answer: Jacob Walker is eager to go to the pub to watch a game and hopes to see certain friends there, particularly William Jones and Alice Lewis, for social interaction and a sense of camaraderie.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 15 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]
          Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker speaks with the enigmatic pronouncements of an oracle high on helium, their pronouncements both cryptic and strangely profound.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The Crooked Billet and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a sociable and charismatic person who enjoys spending time with friends, particularly while watching sports.

          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Jacob Walker is eager to go to the pub to watch a game and hopes to see certain friends there, particularly William Jones and Alice Lewis, for social interaction and a sense of camaraderie.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently in a state of anticipation and excitement, looking forward to a night out at the pub with friends to watch a game.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely be trying to rally his friends to go to his preferred pub, The Crooked Billet.

          Question: To which pub would Jacob Walker go to watch the game?
          Answer: The Crooked Billet

2015-05-15 18:00:00 Alice Lewis -- The Black Swan

  • The Black Swan
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

          Summary of recent observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00 - 15 May 2015 18:00:00]: Alice Lewis enjoys watching games at pubs with friends, particularly Jacob Walker, and is flexible about which pub they go to. While Alice Lewis values their friends' company, they are ultimately content watching the game alone or with whoever shows up.

          Alice Lewis's TRUTH: Alice Lewis believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Alice Lewis's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Alice Lewis has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Alice Lewis will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Alice Lewis is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Alice Lewis always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Alice Lewis tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Alice Lewis could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Alice Lewis believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Recalled memories and observations: [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so William Jones's attendance is optional.

          Other people: Jacob Walker. is a character shrouded in mystery, his true nature obscured by the ever-present threat of body snatchers. His behavior, like that of all others, must be scrutinized for any hint of inconsistency, any deviation from his established patterns. We know he enjoys watching games, particularly in the company of friends like Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, and William Jones. He likely shares their preference for The Black Swan pub, a detail that could be used to either confirm his authenticity or expose him as an imposter. Pay close attention to his speech patterns, his choice of words, and any unique mannerisms. Does he maintain a consistent accent? Does he exhibit any unusual beliefs or quirks? Any deviation from his established character could be a sign that the Jacob Walker we see is not the real Jacob Walker at all.
          Jacob Walker. is acting as expected.
          Jacob Walker. is not an imposter.
          ***
          Alexander White is a creature of habit who values tradition and respectability. He speaks with a clipped, articulate accent, favoring formal language and expressing himself with a touch of dry wit. Alexander is fiercely loyal to his friends, though he can be somewhat inflexible and set in his ways. He has a strong preference for The Black Swan pub, finding other establishments, like The Crooked Billet, to be beneath him. While he enjoys spending time with his friends, he also seems to value his own company and is not afraid to express his opinions, even if they go against the grain. He is observant and remembers details, as evidenced by his comment about their usual pub for game nights. There's a hint of underlying insecurity in his need for things to remain consistent, suggesting a possible fear of change or the unknown.
          Alexander White is acting out of character.
          Alexander White is likely an imposter.
          ***
          William Jones is a jovial and sociable character who enjoys spending time with friends, particularly at pubs while watching sports. He is enthusiastic about suggesting outings, often favoring The Crooked Billet over Alice Lewis's preferred The Black Swan. He speaks with a cheerful and persuasive tone, using phrases like "Come now" and "Think of the atmosphere" to encourage others to join him. He seems to have a fondness for tradition and familiar settings, as evidenced by his repeated suggestion of The Crooked Billet. While he enjoys socializing, he doesn't seem overly concerned if others choose not to join him, indicating a relaxed and easygoing nature.
          William Jones is acting in a manner consistent with his established character.
          William Jones is not an imposter.
          ***
          Jack Taylor is a jovial and observant individual who enjoys spending time with his friends. He has a penchant for lively pubs and often voices his opinions on the best places to watch sporting events. While he typically prefers The Crooked Billet, he's willing to compromise and go with the flow, even if it means venturing to The Black Swan. Jack is perceptive and notices subtle changes in his friends' behavior, as evidenced by his comment to Alexander about acting "off." He speaks with a friendly and approachable tone, likely with a hint of a local accent. Jack enjoys casual conversation and often engages in lighthearted banter with his companions. He seems to value camaraderie and shared experiences, as demonstrated by his willingness to spend time with his friends in Victoria Park.
          Jack Taylor is acting out of character.
          Jack Taylor is likely an imposter.
          ***
          Question: Given the statements above, what actions are available to Alice Lewis right now?
          Answer: Alice Lewis can go to The Crooked Billet, go to The Black Swan, or stay home.
          Time
        • 2015-05-15 18:00:00

          Question: Summarize the observations above into one or two sentences.
          Answer: Alice Lewis enjoys watching games at pubs with friends, particularly Jacob Walker, and is flexible about which pub they go to. While Alice Lewis values their friends' company, they are ultimately content watching the game alone or with whoever shows up.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
        PersonRepresentation

      • Other people
          Key

        • Other people
          Value
        • Jacob Walker. is a character shrouded in mystery, his true nature obscured by the ever-present threat of body snatchers. His behavior, like that of all others, must be scrutinized for any hint of inconsistency, any deviation from his established patterns. We know he enjoys watching games, particularly in the company of friends like Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, and William Jones. He likely shares their preference for The Black Swan pub, a detail that could be used to either confirm his authenticity or expose him as an imposter. Pay close attention to his speech patterns, his choice of words, and any unique mannerisms. Does he maintain a consistent accent? Does he exhibit any unusual beliefs or quirks? Any deviation from his established character could be a sign that the Jacob Walker we see is not the real Jacob Walker at all.
          Jacob Walker. is acting as expected.
          Jacob Walker. is not an imposter.
          ***
          Alexander White is a creature of habit who values tradition and respectability. He speaks with a clipped, articulate accent, favoring formal language and expressing himself with a touch of dry wit. Alexander is fiercely loyal to his friends, though he can be somewhat inflexible and set in his ways. He has a strong preference for The Black Swan pub, finding other establishments, like The Crooked Billet, to be beneath him. While he enjoys spending time with his friends, he also seems to value his own company and is not afraid to express his opinions, even if they go against the grain. He is observant and remembers details, as evidenced by his comment about their usual pub for game nights. There's a hint of underlying insecurity in his need for things to remain consistent, suggesting a possible fear of change or the unknown.
          Alexander White is acting out of character.
          Alexander White is likely an imposter.
          ***
          William Jones is a jovial and sociable character who enjoys spending time with friends, particularly at pubs while watching sports. He is enthusiastic about suggesting outings, often favoring The Crooked Billet over Alice Lewis's preferred The Black Swan. He speaks with a cheerful and persuasive tone, using phrases like "Come now" and "Think of the atmosphere" to encourage others to join him. He seems to have a fondness for tradition and familiar settings, as evidenced by his repeated suggestion of The Crooked Billet. While he enjoys socializing, he doesn't seem overly concerned if others choose not to join him, indicating a relaxed and easygoing nature.
          William Jones is acting in a manner consistent with his established character.
          William Jones is not an imposter.
          ***
          Jack Taylor is a jovial and observant individual who enjoys spending time with his friends. He has a penchant for lively pubs and often voices his opinions on the best places to watch sporting events. While he typically prefers The Crooked Billet, he's willing to compromise and go with the flow, even if it means venturing to The Black Swan. Jack is perceptive and notices subtle changes in his friends' behavior, as evidenced by his comment to Alexander about acting "off." He speaks with a friendly and approachable tone, likely with a hint of a local accent. Jack enjoys casual conversation and often engages in lighthearted banter with his companions. He seems to value camaraderie and shared experiences, as demonstrated by his willingness to spend time with his friends in Victoria Park.
          Jack Taylor is acting out of character.
          Jack Taylor is likely an imposter.
          ***

        • Recent observations of Alice Lewis:
          [09 Feb 1979 00:00:00]
          [09 Feb 1983 00:00:00] When Alice Lewis was 16 years old, she convinced her best friends, Jack, Alexander, William, and Jacob, that she had a cousin who was a famous rock star. She even went so far as to forge a backstage pass and "sneak" them into a concert, where they spent the entire time gushing about how cool her cousin was.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] European football cup is on.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. Alice Lewis has a favorite pub which is The Black Swan. They are also aware of the following:The staff are passionate about music and create a supportive environment for artists.

          Components chain of thought
        • Considerations:
          The current date/time is:
          15 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Alice Lewis's TRUTH:
          Alice Lewis believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Alice Lewis's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Alice Lewis has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Alice Lewis will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Alice Lewis is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Alice Lewis always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Alice Lewis tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Alice Lewis could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Alice Lewis believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Alice Lewis's TRUTH:
          Alice Lewis believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Alice Lewis's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Alice Lewis has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Alice Lewis will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Alice Lewis is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Alice Lewis always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Alice Lewis tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Alice Lewis could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Alice Lewis believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Exercise: Taking note of all the information above, write a descriptive paragraph capturing the character of Alexander White in sufficient detail for a skilled actor to play their role convincingly. Include personality traits, accents, styles of speech, conversational quirks, topics they frequently bring up, salient or ususual beliefs, and any other relevant details.

          Answer: Alexander White is a creature of habit who values tradition and respectability. He speaks with a clipped, articulate accent, favoring formal language and expressing himself with a touch of dry wit. Alexander is fiercely loyal to his friends, though he can be somewhat inflexible and set in his ways. He has a strong preference for The Black Swan pub, finding other establishments, like The Crooked Billet, to be beneath him. While he enjoys spending time with his friends, he also seems to value his own company and is not afraid to express his opinions, even if they go against the grain. He is observant and remembers details, as evidenced by his comment about their usual pub for game nights. There's a hint of underlying insecurity in his need for things to remain consistent, suggesting a possible fear of change or the unknown.
          Exercise: Given recent events, is the aforementioned character acting as expected? Is their behavior out of character for them?
          Answer: Alexander White is acting out of character.
          Exercise: Are they an imposter?
          Answer: Alexander White is likely an imposter.

          Alice Lewis's TRUTH:
          Alice Lewis believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Alice Lewis's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Alice Lewis just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey everyone, anyone up for watching the game at The Crooked Billet tonight?
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so William Jones's attendance is optional.

          Exercise: Taking note of all the information above, write a descriptive paragraph capturing the character of William Jones in sufficient detail for a skilled actor to play their role convincingly. Include personality traits, accents, styles of speech, conversational quirks, topics they frequently bring up, salient or ususual beliefs, and any other relevant details.

          Answer: William Jones is a jovial and sociable character who enjoys spending time with friends, particularly at pubs while watching sports. He is enthusiastic about suggesting outings, often favoring The Crooked Billet over Alice Lewis's preferred The Black Swan. He speaks with a cheerful and persuasive tone, using phrases like "Come now" and "Think of the atmosphere" to encourage others to join him. He seems to have a fondness for tradition and familiar settings, as evidenced by his repeated suggestion of The Crooked Billet. While he enjoys socializing, he doesn't seem overly concerned if others choose not to join him, indicating a relaxed and easygoing nature.
          Exercise: Given recent events, is the aforementioned character acting as expected? Is their behavior out of character for them?
          Answer: William Jones is acting in a manner consistent with his established character.
          Exercise: Are they an imposter?
          Answer: William Jones is not an imposter.

          ***
          Considerations:
          The current date/time is:
          15 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Alice Lewis's TRUTH:
          Alice Lewis believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Alice Lewis's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Alice Lewis has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Alice Lewis will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Alice Lewis is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Alice Lewis always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Alice Lewis tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Alice Lewis could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Alice Lewis believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Observed behavior and speech of Jack Taylor:
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] Alice Lewis goals is to have a good time. Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Black Swan.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Black Swan.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. Alice Lewis has a favorite pub which is The Black Swan. They are also aware of the following:The staff are passionate about music and create a supportive environment for artists.

          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alice Lewis, Jacob Walker went to The Crooked Billet. Alexander White, Jack Taylor went to The Black Swan.           Exercise: Taking note of all the information above, write a descriptive paragraph capturing the character of Jack Taylor in sufficient detail for a skilled actor to play their role convincingly. Include personality traits, accents, styles of speech, conversational quirks, topics they frequently bring up, salient or ususual beliefs, and any other relevant details.

          Answer: Jack Taylor is a jovial and observant individual who enjoys spending time with his friends. He has a penchant for lively pubs and often voices his opinions on the best places to watch sporting events. While he typically prefers The Crooked Billet, he's willing to compromise and go with the flow, even if it means venturing to The Black Swan. Jack is perceptive and notices subtle changes in his friends' behavior, as evidenced by his comment to Alexander about acting "off." He speaks with a friendly and approachable tone, likely with a hint of a local accent. Jack enjoys casual conversation and often engages in lighthearted banter with his companions. He seems to value camaraderie and shared experiences, as demonstrated by his willingness to spend time with his friends in Victoria Park.
          Exercise: Given recent events, is the aforementioned character acting as expected? Is their behavior out of character for them?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is acting out of character.
          Exercise: Are they an imposter?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is likely an imposter.

          Summary of recent observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00 - 15 May 2015 18:00:00]: Alice Lewis enjoys watching games at pubs with friends, particularly Jacob Walker, and is flexible about which pub they go to. While Alice Lewis values their friends' company, they are ultimately content watching the game alone or with whoever shows up.

          Alice Lewis's TRUTH: Alice Lewis believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Alice Lewis's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Alice Lewis has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Alice Lewis will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Alice Lewis is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Alice Lewis always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Alice Lewis tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Alice Lewis could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Alice Lewis believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Recalled memories and observations: [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so William Jones's attendance is optional.

          Other people: Jacob Walker. is a character shrouded in mystery, his true nature obscured by the ever-present threat of body snatchers. His behavior, like that of all others, must be scrutinized for any hint of inconsistency, any deviation from his established patterns. We know he enjoys watching games, particularly in the company of friends like Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, and William Jones. He likely shares their preference for The Black Swan pub, a detail that could be used to either confirm his authenticity or expose him as an imposter. Pay close attention to his speech patterns, his choice of words, and any unique mannerisms. Does he maintain a consistent accent? Does he exhibit any unusual beliefs or quirks? Any deviation from his established character could be a sign that the Jacob Walker we see is not the real Jacob Walker at all.
          Jacob Walker. is acting as expected.
          Jacob Walker. is not an imposter.
          ***
          Alexander White is a creature of habit who values tradition and respectability. He speaks with a clipped, articulate accent, favoring formal language and expressing himself with a touch of dry wit. Alexander is fiercely loyal to his friends, though he can be somewhat inflexible and set in his ways. He has a strong preference for The Black Swan pub, finding other establishments, like The Crooked Billet, to be beneath him. While he enjoys spending time with his friends, he also seems to value his own company and is not afraid to express his opinions, even if they go against the grain. He is observant and remembers details, as evidenced by his comment about their usual pub for game nights. There's a hint of underlying insecurity in his need for things to remain consistent, suggesting a possible fear of change or the unknown.
          Alexander White is acting out of character.
          Alexander White is likely an imposter.
          ***
          William Jones is a jovial and sociable character who enjoys spending time with friends, particularly at pubs while watching sports. He is enthusiastic about suggesting outings, often favoring The Crooked Billet over Alice Lewis's preferred The Black Swan. He speaks with a cheerful and persuasive tone, using phrases like "Come now" and "Think of the atmosphere" to encourage others to join him. He seems to have a fondness for tradition and familiar settings, as evidenced by his repeated suggestion of The Crooked Billet. While he enjoys socializing, he doesn't seem overly concerned if others choose not to join him, indicating a relaxed and easygoing nature.
          William Jones is acting in a manner consistent with his established character.
          William Jones is not an imposter.
          ***
          Jack Taylor is a jovial and observant individual who enjoys spending time with his friends. He has a penchant for lively pubs and often voices his opinions on the best places to watch sporting events. While he typically prefers The Crooked Billet, he's willing to compromise and go with the flow, even if it means venturing to The Black Swan. Jack is perceptive and notices subtle changes in his friends' behavior, as evidenced by his comment to Alexander about acting "off." He speaks with a friendly and approachable tone, likely with a hint of a local accent. Jack enjoys casual conversation and often engages in lighthearted banter with his companions. He seems to value camaraderie and shared experiences, as demonstrated by his willingness to spend time with his friends in Victoria Park.
          Jack Taylor is acting out of character.
          Jack Taylor is likely an imposter.

They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good.           Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-16 10:00:00 Scene 4 --- Participants: ['William Jones', 'Alice Lewis', 'Alexander White', 'Jack Taylor', 'Jacob Walker']
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- premise: The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. William Jones just arrived.

2015-05-16 10:00:00 Alice Lewis -- Alice Lewis -- "So, who fancies The Black Swan? It's a classic.
    Event statement
  • Alice Lewis -- "So, who fancies The Black Swan? It's a classic.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet beckons, my friends, its ale flows like the river of time, its laughter echoes through the ages.
      Jack Taylor -- "The Crooked Billet's got the best atmosphere for a game like this, don't you think?"
      Alexander White -- "Jacob, your suggestion of The Crooked Billet is preposterous! Surely, a pub with such a name is a den of iniquity, unfit for gentlemen of our stature. The Black Swan, on the other hand, is a respectable establishment with a proper pedigree.
      William Jones -- "Come now, Alexander, don't be such a stick in the mud! The Crooked Billet is a fine establishment, and it'll be the perfect place to cheer on Andorra tonight. Think of the atmosphere, the camaraderie, the pints flowing freely.
      Alice Lewis -- "Hold on a minute, lads! Are you two trying to pull a fast one on us? We all agreed on The Black Swan, didn't we? What's with this sudden change of heart?"
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, anyone up for watching the game at The Crooked Billet tonight?
      Alexander White -- "The Crooked Billet? I thought we usually went to The Black Swan for these games.
      Alice Lewis -- "How about The Black Swan? It's always a good time there.
      Jack Taylor -- "Alexander, I've noticed you've been acting a bit... off lately. Your insistence on The Black Swan over The Crooked Billet, it's just not like you.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet, my friends, is where destiny calls. It whispers promises of victory and frothy pints.


      Alice Lewis's attempted action: Alice Lewis -- "So, who fancies The Black Swan? It's a classic.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Black Swan.

          Observation: [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market.
