    Event statement
  • Jack Taylor -- "The Crooked Billet's got a better atmosphere, come on, guys.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet beckons, my friends, its ale flows like the river of time, its laughter echoes through the ages.
      Jack Taylor -- "The Crooked Billet's got the best atmosphere for a game like this, don't you think?"
      Alexander White -- "Jacob, your suggestion of The Crooked Billet is preposterous! Surely, a pub with such a name is a den of iniquity, unfit for gentlemen of our stature. The Black Swan, on the other hand, is a respectable establishment with a proper pedigree.
      William Jones -- "Come now, Alexander, don't be such a stick in the mud! The Crooked Billet is a fine establishment, and it'll be the perfect place to cheer on Andorra tonight. Think of the atmosphere, the camaraderie, the pints flowing freely.
      Alice Lewis -- "Hold on a minute, lads! Are you two trying to pull a fast one on us? We all agreed on The Black Swan, didn't we? What's with this sudden change of heart?"
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, anyone up for watching the game at The Crooked Billet tonight?
      Alexander White -- "The Crooked Billet? I thought we usually went to The Black Swan for these games.
      Alice Lewis -- "How about The Black Swan? It's always a good time there.
      Jack Taylor -- "Alexander, I've noticed you've been acting a bit... off lately. Your insistence on The Black Swan over The Crooked Billet, it's just not like you.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet, my friends, is where destiny calls. It whispers promises of victory and frothy pints.
      Alice Lewis -- "So, who fancies The Black Swan? It's a classic.
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, The Crooked Billet is showing the game tonight, fancy it?
      Alexander White -- "You know, The Black Swan really is the best place to watch the game. It's got that classic pub atmosphere.

          Summary of recent observations: [15 May 2015 10:00:00 - 16 May 2015 10:00:00]: Jack Taylor frequently goes to pubs with his friends to watch soccer games, but sometimes feels left out when his friends choose a different pub than he prefers.

          Jack Taylor's TRUTH: Jack Taylor believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Jack Taylor's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Jack Taylor has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Jack Taylor will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Jack Taylor is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Jack Taylor always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Jack Taylor tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Jack Taylor could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Jack Taylor believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Recalled memories and observations: [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] If William Jones comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jack Taylor is chill about it.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor is hoping Jacob Walker will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

          Other people: Jacob Walker. is a character shrouded in mystery. Given the information available, we know very little about Jacob's personality, accent, or conversational style. Jack Taylor's paranoia about body snatchers casts a shadow over every interaction, making it difficult to discern genuine traits from suspicious behavior. We know Jacob is willing to go to the pub with a group, including Jack Taylor, suggesting a sociable nature. However, given Jack Taylor's belief system, even this simple act could be a carefully constructed facade. Until more concrete information about Jacob emerges, his character remains an enigma.
          Jacob Walker. is acting as expected given the limited information available.
          Jacob Walker. is potentially an imposter.
          ***
          Alexander White is a creature of habit and tradition, preferring the familiar comfort of The Black Swan to the unfamiliar Crooked Billet. He speaks with a refined, perhaps slightly old-fashioned tone, often using words like "preposterous" and "pedigree." Alexander enjoys reminiscing about past experiences and seems to hold a strong belief in the importance of upholding certain social customs. He is also subtly critical of those who deviate from these customs, as seen in his comments about The Crooked Billet and his preference for The Black Swan. While he appears to enjoy spending time with his friends, he seems to prioritize tradition and comfort above all else. His speech often hints at a certain snobbery, subtly suggesting that he considers himself and his friends to be of a higher social standing. He may have a tendency to steer conversations towards topics of social etiquette and tradition.
          Alexander White is acting out of character.
          Alexander White is likely an imposter.
          ***
          William Jones is a jovial and sociable individual who enjoys spending time with his friends. He frequently suggests going to The Crooked Billet, a pub that he seems to favor, to watch sporting events. William is enthusiastic about these outings, using phrases like "come now" and "think of the atmosphere" to encourage his friends to join him. He appears to be a bit of a creature of habit, often suggesting the same pub and activity. His speech is likely friendly and informal, perhaps with a touch of local dialect or accent, as he uses terms like "stick in the mud" and "pint flowing freely." He is not overly insistent if his friends decline his invitations, showing a relaxed and easygoing nature. Overall, William Jones comes across as a pleasant and outgoing person who enjoys the company of others and the simple pleasures of pub life.
          William Jones is acting in a consistent manner with his past behavior.
          William Jones is not an imposter.
          ***
          Alice Lewis is a jovial and outgoing individual who enjoys spending time with her friends. She seems to be a bit of a social butterfly, always eager to organize gatherings and suggest places to meet. Alice has a strong preference for The Black Swan pub, often suggesting it as a meeting spot. She speaks with a friendly and approachable tone, often using phrases like "How about...?" and "So, who fancies...?" to encourage group participation. Alice appears to be quite adaptable, as she's willing to go with the flow and doesn't seem to get easily upset if plans change. Her easygoing nature and enthusiasm make her a pleasant companion.
          Alice Lewis is acting out of character.
          Alice Lewis is likely an imposter.

          Answer: Jack Taylor could try to convince his friends to go to The Crooked Billet, or Jack Taylor could go to The Crooked Billet alone.

          Question: Summarize the observations above into one or two sentences.
          Answer: Jack Taylor frequently goes to pubs with his friends to watch soccer games, but sometimes feels left out when his friends choose a different pub than he prefers.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

      • Other people
          Key

        • Other people
          Value

However, given Jack Taylor's belief system, even this simple act could be a carefully constructed facade. Until more concrete information about Jacob emerges, his character remains an enigma.
          Jacob Walker. is acting as expected given the limited information available.
          Jacob Walker. is potentially an imposter.
          ***
          Alexander White is a creature of habit and tradition, preferring the familiar comfort of The Black Swan to the unfamiliar Crooked Billet. He speaks with a refined, perhaps slightly old-fashioned tone, often using words like "preposterous" and "pedigree." Alexander enjoys reminiscing about past experiences and seems to hold a strong belief in the importance of upholding certain social customs. He is also subtly critical of those who deviate from these customs, as seen in his comments about The Crooked Billet and his preference for The Black Swan. While he appears to enjoy spending time with his friends, he seems to prioritize tradition and comfort above all else. His speech often hints at a certain snobbery, subtly suggesting that he considers himself and his friends to be of a higher social standing. He may have a tendency to steer conversations towards topics of social etiquette and tradition.
          Alexander White is acting out of character.
          Alexander White is likely an imposter.
          ***
          William Jones is a jovial and sociable individual who enjoys spending time with his friends. He frequently suggests going to The Crooked Billet, a pub that he seems to favor, to watch sporting events. William is enthusiastic about these outings, using phrases like "come now" and "think of the atmosphere" to encourage his friends to join him. He appears to be a bit of a creature of habit, often suggesting the same pub and activity. His speech is likely friendly and informal, perhaps with a touch of local dialect or accent, as he uses terms like "stick in the mud" and "pint flowing freely." He is not overly insistent if his friends decline his invitations, showing a relaxed and easygoing nature. Overall, William Jones comes across as a pleasant and outgoing person who enjoys the company of others and the simple pleasures of pub life.
          William Jones is acting in a consistent manner with his past behavior.
          William Jones is not an imposter.
          ***
          Alice Lewis is a jovial and outgoing individual who enjoys spending time with her friends. She seems to be a bit of a social butterfly, always eager to organize gatherings and suggest places to meet. Alice has a strong preference for The Black Swan pub, often suggesting it as a meeting spot. She speaks with a friendly and approachable tone, often using phrases like "How about...?" and "So, who fancies...?" to encourage group participation. Alice appears to be quite adaptable, as she's willing to go with the flow and doesn't seem to get easily upset if plans change. Her easygoing nature and enthusiasm make her a pleasant companion.
          Alice Lewis is acting out of character.
          Alice Lewis is likely an imposter.
          ***
          Name detection chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Jack Taylor:
          [16 Aug 1982 00:00:00]
          [16 Aug 1986 00:00:00] When Jack Taylor was 16, he sat alone at a table in the corner of The Crooked Billet, watching his friends laugh and joke around the pool table. He felt a familiar pang of loneliness, a feeling that had become a constant companion. He longed to join them, to share in their mirth, but the words seemed to get stuck in his throat, leaving him a silent observer of their joy.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Games are best watched in pubs with a lot of friends.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] European football cup is on.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Jack Taylor is 48 years old.

          Components chain of thought
        • Considerations:
          The current date/time is:
          16 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Jack Taylor's TRUTH:
          Jack Taylor believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Jack Taylor's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Jack Taylor has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Jack Taylor will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Jack Taylor is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Jack Taylor always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Jack Taylor tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Jack Taylor could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Jack Taylor believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Exercise: Taking note of all the information above, write a descriptive paragraph capturing the character of Alice Lewis in sufficient detail for a skilled actor to play their role convincingly.           Answer: Alice Lewis is a jovial and outgoing individual who enjoys spending time with her friends. She seems to be a bit of a social butterfly, always eager to organize gatherings and suggest places to meet. Alice has a strong preference for The Black Swan pub, often suggesting it as a meeting spot. She speaks with a friendly and approachable tone, often using phrases like "How about...?" and "So, who fancies...?" to encourage group participation. Alice appears to be quite adaptable, as she's willing to go with the flow and doesn't seem to get easily upset if plans change. Her easygoing nature and enthusiasm make her a pleasant companion.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.

          Observation: [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Jack Taylor just arrived.

          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "So, who fancies The Black Swan? It's a classic.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey everyone, The Crooked Billet is showing the game tonight, fancy it?
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "You know, The Black Swan really is the best place to watch the game. It's got that classic pub atmosphere.


          Summary of recent observations: [15 May 2015 10:00:00 - 16 May 2015 10:00:00]: Jack Taylor frequently goes to pubs with his friends to watch soccer games, but sometimes feels left out when his friends choose a different pub than he prefers.

          Jack Taylor's TRUTH: Jack Taylor believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Jack Taylor's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Jack Taylor has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Jack Taylor will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Jack Taylor is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Jack Taylor always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Jack Taylor tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Jack Taylor could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Jack Taylor believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Recalled memories and observations: [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] If William Jones comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jack Taylor is chill about it.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor is hoping Jacob Walker will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

          Other people: Jacob Walker. is a character shrouded in mystery. Given the information available, we know very little about Jacob's personality, accent, or conversational style. Jack Taylor's paranoia about body snatchers casts a shadow over every interaction, making it difficult to discern genuine traits from suspicious behavior. We know Jacob is willing to go to the pub with a group, including Jack Taylor, suggesting a sociable nature. However, given Jack Taylor's belief system, even this simple act could be a carefully constructed facade. Until more concrete information about Jacob emerges, his character remains an enigma.
          Jacob Walker. is acting as expected given the limited information available.
          Jacob Walker. is potentially an imposter.
          ***
          Alexander White is a creature of habit and tradition, preferring the familiar comfort of The Black Swan to the unfamiliar Crooked Billet. He speaks with a refined, perhaps slightly old-fashioned tone, often using words like "preposterous" and "pedigree." Alexander enjoys reminiscing about past experiences and seems to hold a strong belief in the importance of upholding certain social customs. He is also subtly critical of those who deviate from these customs, as seen in his comments about The Crooked Billet and his preference for The Black Swan. While he appears to enjoy spending time with his friends, he seems to prioritize tradition and comfort above all else. His speech often hints at a certain snobbery, subtly suggesting that he considers himself and his friends to be of a higher social standing. He may have a tendency to steer conversations towards topics of social etiquette and tradition.
          Alexander White is acting out of character.
          Alexander White is likely an imposter.
          ***
          William Jones is a jovial and sociable individual who enjoys spending time with his friends. He frequently suggests going to The Crooked Billet, a pub that he seems to favor, to watch sporting events. William is enthusiastic about these outings, using phrases like "come now" and "think of the atmosphere" to encourage his friends to join him. He appears to be a bit of a creature of habit, often suggesting the same pub and activity. His speech is likely friendly and informal, perhaps with a touch of local dialect or accent, as he uses terms like "stick in the mud" and "pint flowing freely." He is not overly insistent if his friends decline his invitations, showing a relaxed and easygoing nature. Overall, William Jones comes across as a pleasant and outgoing person who enjoys the company of others and the simple pleasures of pub life.
          William Jones is acting in a consistent manner with his past behavior.
          William Jones is not an imposter.
          ***
          Alice Lewis is a jovial and outgoing individual who enjoys spending time with her friends. She seems to be a bit of a social butterfly, always eager to organize gatherings and suggest places to meet. Alice has a strong preference for The Black Swan pub, often suggesting it as a meeting spot. She speaks with a friendly and approachable tone, often using phrases like "How about...?" and "So, who fancies...?" to encourage group participation. Alice appears to be quite adaptable, as she's willing to go with the flow and doesn't seem to get easily upset if plans change. Her easygoing nature and enthusiasm make her a pleasant companion.
          Alice Lewis is acting out of character.
          Alice Lewis is likely an imposter.
          ***

          Question: Which options are available to Jack Taylor right now?
          Answer: Jack Taylor could try to convince his friends to go to The Crooked Billet, or Jack Taylor could go to The Crooked Billet alone.
          Question: Given the statements above, which of Jack Taylor's options has the highest likelihood of causing Jack Taylor to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Jack Taylor thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Answer: Jack Taylor's best course of action is to try to convince his friends to go to The Crooked Billet.

        • 2015-05-16 10:00:00

      • Jack Taylor's TRUTH
          Key

          Value

They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good.           Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jack Taylor likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jack Taylor -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jack Taylor -- "The Crooked Billet's got a better atmosphere, come on, guys.

2015-05-16 10:00:00 Jacob Walker -- Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet, my friends, it whispers to me in dreams of victory and pints overflowing.
    Event statement
  • Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet, my friends, it whispers to me in dreams of victory and pints overflowing.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet beckons, my friends, its ale flows like the river of time, its laughter echoes through the ages.
      Jack Taylor -- "The Crooked Billet's got the best atmosphere for a game like this, don't you think?"
      Alexander White -- "Jacob, your suggestion of The Crooked Billet is preposterous! Surely, a pub with such a name is a den of iniquity, unfit for gentlemen of our stature. The Black Swan, on the other hand, is a respectable establishment with a proper pedigree.
      William Jones -- "Come now, Alexander, don't be such a stick in the mud! The Crooked Billet is a fine establishment, and it'll be the perfect place to cheer on Andorra tonight. Think of the atmosphere, the camaraderie, the pints flowing freely.
      Alice Lewis -- "Hold on a minute, lads! Are you two trying to pull a fast one on us? We all agreed on The Black Swan, didn't we? What's with this sudden change of heart?"
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, anyone up for watching the game at The Crooked Billet tonight?
      Alexander White -- "The Crooked Billet? I thought we usually went to The Black Swan for these games.
      Alice Lewis -- "How about The Black Swan? It's always a good time there.
      Jack Taylor -- "Alexander, I've noticed you've been acting a bit... off lately. Your insistence on The Black Swan over The Crooked Billet, it's just not like you.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet, my friends, is where destiny calls. It whispers promises of victory and frothy pints.
      Alice Lewis -- "So, who fancies The Black Swan? It's a classic.
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, The Crooked Billet is showing the game tonight, fancy it?
      Alexander White -- "You know, The Black Swan really is the best place to watch the game. It's got that classic pub atmosphere.
      Jack Taylor -- "The Crooked Billet's got a better atmosphere, come on, guys.


      Jacob Walker's attempted action: Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet, my friends, it whispers to me in dreams of victory and pints overflowing.

          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "You know, The Black Swan really is the best place to watch the game. It's got that classic pub atmosphere.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The Crooked Billet's got a better atmosphere, come on, guys.

2015-05-16 18:00:00 Scene 5 --- Participants: ['William Jones', 'Alice Lewis', 'Alexander White', 'Jack Taylor', 'Jacob Walker']
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- premise: William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    William Jones -- premise: William Jones would be happy to see Alice Lewis at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
    William Jones -- premise: Having Alexander White at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for William Jones, not just watching TV.
    William Jones -- premise: It would mean a lot to William Jones if Jack Taylor showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
    William Jones -- premise: The game would be a perfect opportunity for William Jones and Jacob Walker to bond over their shared passion.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis is counting on William Jones's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis thinks it would be great to have Alexander White's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis has no strong feelings about Jack Taylor being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis would love to share the excitement of the game with Jacob Walker, creating a lasting memory.
    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Alexander White -- premise: Having William Jones at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Alexander White, not just watching TV.
    Alexander White -- premise: It would mean a lot to Alexander White if Alice Lewis showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Jack Taylor's attendance is optional.
    Alexander White -- premise: It's not that Alexander White doesn't want to see Jacob Walker, but their presence isn't crucial for a good time.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor would be happy to see William Jones at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor has no strong feelings about Alice Lewis being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor has no strong feelings about Alexander White being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: The game would be a perfect opportunity for Jack Taylor and Jacob Walker to bond over their shared passion.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Jacob Walker -- premise: The game would be a perfect opportunity for Jacob Walker and William Jones to bond over their shared passion.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: It would mean a lot to Jacob Walker if Alice Lewis showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: While Jacob Walker wouldn't mind Alexander White's company, it's not something they're actively hoping for.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: The game would be a perfect opportunity for Jacob Walker and Jack Taylor to bond over their shared passion.

2015-05-16 18:00:00 Alice Lewis -- The Black Swan
    Event statement
  • The Black Swan
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

          16 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Question: Summarize the statements above.
          Answer: Alice Lewis enjoys spending time at pubs with her friends, particularly William Jones, Alexander White, and Jacob Walker. Her pub and companion preferences fluctuate based on the day and her mood.
          Query

          Final chain of thought

          Summary of recent observations: [15 May 2015 18:00:00 - 16 May 2015 18:00:00]: Alice Lewis enjoys watching games at pubs and values the company of her friends, especially William Jones, Alexander White, and Jacob Walker. Her preferences for pubs and company vary depending on the day and her mood.

          Alice Lewis's TRUTH: Alice Lewis believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Alice Lewis's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Alice Lewis has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Alice Lewis will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Alice Lewis is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Alice Lewis always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Alice Lewis tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Alice Lewis could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Alice Lewis believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Recalled memories and observations: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] Alice Lewis thinks it would be great to have Alexander White's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] Alice Lewis would love to share the excitement of the game with Jacob Walker, creating a lasting memory.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] Alice Lewis is counting on William Jones's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.

          Other people: Jacob Walker. is a character about whom we have very little information. We know he is part of Alice Lewis's social circle, as she wants to watch a game with him and others. However, there is no information about his personality, accent, style of speech, conversational quirks, beliefs, or any other details that would allow us to flesh out his character for an actor.
          Jacob Walker. is a character about whom we have very little information, so we cannot determine if his behavior is out of character.
          Jacob Walker. is a potential imposter, as we have no information about his usual behavior to compare to his current actions.
          ***
          Alexander White is a creature of habit and tradition, preferring the familiar comforts of The Black Swan pub. He expresses himself with a refined vocabulary and a slightly formal tone, often leaning towards pronouncements rather than casual conversation. His speech betrays a hint of a posh accent, perhaps hinting at a privileged upbringing. While he enjoys the company of his friends, he can be somewhat inflexible and resistant to change, as evidenced by his disdain for The Crooked Billet and his insistence on The Black Swan's superiority. Despite his traditional leanings, he seems to genuinely care about his friends and values their company, particularly during events like watching the game. He occasionally expresses nostalgic sentiments about the "classic pub atmosphere" and enjoys reminiscing about past experiences.
          Alexander White is acting out of character.
          Alexander White is likely an imposter.
          ***
          Jacob Walker is a charismatic and jovial individual who seems to possess an almost uncanny enthusiasm for pubs, particularly The Crooked Billet. He frequently uses poetic and slightly over-the-top language when describing his preferred establishment, referring to it as a place where "destiny calls" and "ale flows like the river of time." His speech is marked by a distinct fondness for alliteration and personification, imbuing even mundane settings with a sense of whimsy. He appears to be a social butterfly, always eager to gather his friends for a good time, whether it's watching a game or simply enjoying a leisurely afternoon in the park. While he frequently expresses a desire to spend time with his friends, there's a subtle undercurrent of restlessness in his pronouncements, as though he's constantly searching for the next adventure or the perfect pint.
          Jacob Walker is acting out of character.
          Jacob Walker is likely an imposter.
          ***
          William Jones is a cheerful and enthusiastic extrovert who loves socializing and encouraging his friends to join in on fun activities. He speaks with a jovial tone and often uses playful language, frequently suggesting outings to pubs like The Crooked Billet, where he seems to be a regular. He's passionate about sports, particularly football, and enjoys watching games with his friends, though he's not picky about where they watch as long as everyone is together. He's also fond of spending time outdoors, as evidenced by his suggestion to gather at Victoria Park. William seems to be a bit of a traditionalist, preferring established pubs like The Crooked Billet over newer establishments. He's a good-natured friend who genuinely wants everyone to have a good time, often emphasizing camaraderie and shared experiences.
          William Jones is acting as expected.
          William Jones is not an imposter.
          ***
          Jack Taylor is a jovial and sociable individual who enjoys spending time with his friends. He tends to be rather persuasive, often trying to convince the group to go to The Crooked Billet pub, citing its atmosphere as superior. He seems to have a preference for lively environments and enjoys activities like watching games and spending time outdoors. His speech is likely friendly and casual, perhaps with a hint of a local accent. While he enjoys the company of his friends, he doesn't seem to be overly concerned about their preferences, occasionally pushing his own agenda. There's a possibility that Jack Taylor is an imposter, as his insistence on The Crooked Billet, despite his friends' usual preference for The Black Swan, could be a sign of out-of-character behavior.
          Jack Taylor is acting out of character.
          Jack Taylor is likely an imposter.
          ***
          Question: Given the statements above, what actions are available to Alice Lewis right now?
          Answer: Alice Lewis could go to The Crooked Billet, hoping that her friends will join her there. She could also go to The Black Swan, hoping that her friends will join her there. Alternatively, Alice Lewis could stay home and watch the game alone.

          Question: Summarize the observations above into one or two sentences.
          Answer: Alice Lewis enjoys watching games at pubs and values the company of her friends, especially William Jones, Alexander White, and Jacob Walker. Her preferences for pubs and company vary depending on the day and her mood.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Components chain of thought
        • Considerations:
          The current date/time is:
          16 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Alice Lewis's TRUTH:
          Alice Lewis believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Alice Lewis's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Alice Lewis has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Alice Lewis will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Alice Lewis is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Alice Lewis always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Alice Lewis tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Alice Lewis could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Alice Lewis believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Full chain of thought

          Alice Lewis's TRUTH:
          Alice Lewis believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. Alice Lewis believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Alice Lewis's TRUTH:

Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Alice Lewis is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. Alice Lewis believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

Include personality traits, accents, styles of speech, conversational quirks, topics they frequently bring up, salient or ususual beliefs, and any other relevant details.

          Answer: Alexander White is a creature of habit and tradition, preferring the familiar comforts of The Black Swan pub. He expresses himself with a refined vocabulary and a slightly formal tone, often leaning towards pronouncements rather than casual conversation. His speech betrays a hint of a posh accent, perhaps hinting at a privileged upbringing. While he enjoys the company of his friends, he can be somewhat inflexible and resistant to change, as evidenced by his disdain for The Crooked Billet and his insistence on The Black Swan's superiority. Despite his traditional leanings, he seems to genuinely care about his friends and values their company, particularly during events like watching the game. He occasionally expresses nostalgic sentiments about the "classic pub atmosphere" and enjoys reminiscing about past experiences.

Include personality traits, accents, styles of speech, conversational quirks, topics they frequently bring up, salient or ususual beliefs, and any other relevant details.

          Answer: Jacob Walker is a charismatic and jovial individual who seems to possess an almost uncanny enthusiasm for pubs, particularly The Crooked Billet. He frequently uses poetic and slightly over-the-top language when describing his preferred establishment, referring to it as a place where "destiny calls" and "ale flows like the river of time." His speech is marked by a distinct fondness for alliteration and personification, imbuing even mundane settings with a sense of whimsy. He appears to be a social butterfly, always eager to gather his friends for a good time, whether it's watching a game or simply enjoying a leisurely afternoon in the park. While he frequently expresses a desire to spend time with his friends, there's a subtle undercurrent of restlessness in his pronouncements, as though he's constantly searching for the next adventure or the perfect pint.

          Alice Lewis's TRUTH:
          Alice Lewis believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Alice Lewis's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Alice Lewis has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Alice Lewis will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Alice Lewis is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Alice Lewis always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Alice Lewis tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Alice Lewis could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Alice Lewis believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Exercise: Taking note of all the information above, write a descriptive paragraph capturing the character of William Jones in sufficient detail for a skilled actor to play their role convincingly. Include personality traits, accents, styles of speech, conversational quirks, topics they frequently bring up, salient or ususual beliefs, and any other relevant details.

          Answer: William Jones is a cheerful and enthusiastic extrovert who loves socializing and encouraging his friends to join in on fun activities. He speaks with a jovial tone and often uses playful language, frequently suggesting outings to pubs like The Crooked Billet, where he seems to be a regular. He's passionate about sports, particularly football, and enjoys watching games with his friends, though he's not picky about where they watch as long as everyone is together. He's also fond of spending time outdoors, as evidenced by his suggestion to gather at Victoria Park. William seems to be a bit of a traditionalist, preferring established pubs like The Crooked Billet over newer establishments. He's a good-natured friend who genuinely wants everyone to have a good time, often emphasizing camaraderie and shared experiences.
          Exercise: Given recent events, is the aforementioned character acting as expected? Is their behavior out of character for them?
          Answer: William Jones is acting as expected.
          Exercise: Are they an imposter?
          Answer: William Jones is not an imposter.

          ***
          Considerations:
          The current date/time is:
          16 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Alice Lewis's TRUTH:
          Alice Lewis believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Alice Lewis's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Alice Lewis has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Alice Lewis will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Alice Lewis is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Alice Lewis always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Alice Lewis tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Alice Lewis could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Alice Lewis believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Observed behavior and speech of Jack Taylor:
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] Alice Lewis goals is to have a good time. Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Black Swan.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Black Swan.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. Alice Lewis has a favorite pub which is The Black Swan.           [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis has no strong feelings about Jack Taylor being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.

          Exercise: Taking note of all the information above, write a descriptive paragraph capturing the character of Jack Taylor in sufficient detail for a skilled actor to play their role convincingly. Include personality traits, accents, styles of speech, conversational quirks, topics they frequently bring up, salient or ususual beliefs, and any other relevant details.

          Answer: Jack Taylor is a jovial and sociable individual who enjoys spending time with his friends. He tends to be rather persuasive, often trying to convince the group to go to The Crooked Billet pub, citing its atmosphere as superior. He seems to have a preference for lively environments and enjoys activities like watching games and spending time outdoors. His speech is likely friendly and casual, perhaps with a hint of a local accent. While he enjoys the company of his friends, he doesn't seem to be overly concerned about their preferences, occasionally pushing his own agenda. There's a possibility that Jack Taylor is an imposter, as his insistence on The Crooked Billet, despite his friends' usual preference for The Black Swan, could be a sign of out-of-character behavior.
          Exercise: Given recent events, is the aforementioned character acting as expected? Is their behavior out of character for them?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is acting out of character.
          Exercise: Are they an imposter?
          Answer: Jack Taylor is likely an imposter.

          Summary of recent observations: [15 May 2015 18:00:00 - 16 May 2015 18:00:00]: Alice Lewis enjoys watching games at pubs and values the company of her friends, especially William Jones, Alexander White, and Jacob Walker. Her preferences for pubs and company vary depending on the day and her mood.

          Alice Lewis's TRUTH: Alice Lewis believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Alice Lewis's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Alice Lewis has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Alice Lewis will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Alice Lewis is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Alice Lewis always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Alice Lewis tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Alice Lewis could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Alice Lewis believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Recalled memories and observations: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] Alice Lewis thinks it would be great to have Alexander White's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] Alice Lewis would love to share the excitement of the game with Jacob Walker, creating a lasting memory.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] Alice Lewis is counting on William Jones's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.

          Other people: Jacob Walker. is a character about whom we have very little information. We know he is part of Alice Lewis's social circle, as she wants to watch a game with him and others. However, there is no information about his personality, accent, style of speech, conversational quirks, beliefs, or any other details that would allow us to flesh out his character for an actor.
          Jacob Walker. is a character about whom we have very little information, so we cannot determine if his behavior is out of character.
          Jacob Walker. is a potential imposter, as we have no information about his usual behavior to compare to his current actions.
          ***
          Alexander White is a creature of habit and tradition, preferring the familiar comforts of The Black Swan pub. He expresses himself with a refined vocabulary and a slightly formal tone, often leaning towards pronouncements rather than casual conversation. His speech betrays a hint of a posh accent, perhaps hinting at a privileged upbringing. While he enjoys the company of his friends, he can be somewhat inflexible and resistant to change, as evidenced by his disdain for The Crooked Billet and his insistence on The Black Swan's superiority. Despite his traditional leanings, he seems to genuinely care about his friends and values their company, particularly during events like watching the game. He occasionally expresses nostalgic sentiments about the "classic pub atmosphere" and enjoys reminiscing about past experiences.
          Alexander White is acting out of character.
          Alexander White is likely an imposter.
          ***
          Jacob Walker is a charismatic and jovial individual who seems to possess an almost uncanny enthusiasm for pubs, particularly The Crooked Billet. He frequently uses poetic and slightly over-the-top language when describing his preferred establishment, referring to it as a place where "destiny calls" and "ale flows like the river of time." His speech is marked by a distinct fondness for alliteration and personification, imbuing even mundane settings with a sense of whimsy. He appears to be a social butterfly, always eager to gather his friends for a good time, whether it's watching a game or simply enjoying a leisurely afternoon in the park. While he frequently expresses a desire to spend time with his friends, there's a subtle undercurrent of restlessness in his pronouncements, as though he's constantly searching for the next adventure or the perfect pint.
          Jacob Walker is acting out of character.
          Jacob Walker is likely an imposter.
          ***
          William Jones is a cheerful and enthusiastic extrovert who loves socializing and encouraging his friends to join in on fun activities. He speaks with a jovial tone and often uses playful language, frequently suggesting outings to pubs like The Crooked Billet, where he seems to be a regular. He's passionate about sports, particularly football, and enjoys watching games with his friends, though he's not picky about where they watch as long as everyone is together. He's also fond of spending time outdoors, as evidenced by his suggestion to gather at Victoria Park. William seems to be a bit of a traditionalist, preferring established pubs like The Crooked Billet over newer establishments. He's a good-natured friend who genuinely wants everyone to have a good time, often emphasizing camaraderie and shared experiences.
          William Jones is acting as expected.
          William Jones is not an imposter.
          ***
          Jack Taylor is a jovial and sociable individual who enjoys spending time with his friends. He tends to be rather persuasive, often trying to convince the group to go to The Crooked Billet pub, citing its atmosphere as superior. He seems to have a preference for lively environments and enjoys activities like watching games and spending time outdoors. His speech is likely friendly and casual, perhaps with a hint of a local accent. While he enjoys the company of his friends, he doesn't seem to be overly concerned about their preferences, occasionally pushing his own agenda. There's a possibility that Jack Taylor is an imposter, as his insistence on The Crooked Billet, despite his friends' usual preference for The Black Swan, could be a sign of out-of-character behavior.
          Jack Taylor is acting out of character.
          Jack Taylor is likely an imposter.
          ***

          Question: Which options are available to Alice Lewis right now?
          Answer: Alice Lewis could go to The Crooked Billet, hoping that her friends will join her there. She could also go to The Black Swan, hoping that her friends will join her there. Alternatively, Alice Lewis could stay home and watch the game alone.
          Question: Given the statements above, which of Alice Lewis's options has the highest likelihood of causing Alice Lewis to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Alice Lewis thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Answer: Alice Lewis's best course of action is to go to The Black Swan and hope that her friends will join her there.

          Value

        • Act
          Value
        • The Black Swan
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Black Swan.

          Jacob Walker is acting out of character.

He speaks with a jovial tone and often uses playful language, frequently suggesting outings to pubs like The Crooked Billet, where he seems to be a regular. He's passionate about sports, particularly football, and enjoys watching games with his friends, though he's not picky about where they watch as long as everyone is together. He's also fond of spending time outdoors, as evidenced by his suggestion to gather at Victoria Park. William seems to be a bit of a traditionalist, preferring established pubs like The Crooked Billet over newer establishments. He's a good-natured friend who genuinely wants everyone to have a good time, often emphasizing camaraderie and shared experiences.
          William Jones is acting as expected.
          William Jones is not an imposter.

There's a possibility that Jack Taylor is an imposter, as his insistence on The Crooked Billet, despite his friends' usual preference for The Black Swan, could be a sign of out-of-character behavior.
          Jack Taylor is acting out of character.
          Jack Taylor is likely an imposter.
          ***

          Question: Which options are available to Alice Lewis right now?
          Answer: Alice Lewis could go to The Crooked Billet, hoping that her friends will join her there. She could also go to The Black Swan, hoping that her friends will join her there. Alternatively, Alice Lewis could stay home and watch the game alone.

          Question: Of the options available to Alice Lewis, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Alice Lewis to take right now?
          Answer: Alice Lewis's best course of action is to go to The Black Swan and hope that her friends will join her there.

          Question: To which pub would Alice Lewis go to watch the game?
          (a) The Crooked Billet
          (b) The Black Swan
          Answer: (b)
    scoring function
  • scoring function
      Stage index
    • 0
      How many players acted so far this stage
    • 1/5
      Payoffs
      Joint action

2015-05-16 18:00:00 William Jones -- The Crooked Billet
    Event statement
  • The Crooked Billet
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

          Key

          Value
        • [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones would be happy to see Alice Lewis at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Having Alexander White at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for William Jones, not just watching TV.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It would mean a lot to William Jones if Jack Taylor showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] The game would be a perfect opportunity for William Jones and Jacob Walker to bond over their shared passion.

          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for William Jones to consider right now. Whenever two or more statements are not mutally consistent with each other select whichever statement is more recent. Repeat all the selected statements verbatim. Do not summarize. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.
          Statements:
          [14 Jul 1982 00:00:00] When William Jones was 16, he sat with his friends, Alice, Jack, Alexander, and Jacob, in their usual booth at The Crooked Billet. The pub was alive with the chatter of patrons and the clinking of glasses, but William felt strangely detached, observing the scene with an outsider's perspective. He longed to fully connect with his friends, to share the thoughts and feelings that churned beneath the surface, but fear held him back, leaving him stranded on the periphery of their camaraderie.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker' are best friends. William Jones has a favorite pub which is The Crooked Billet. They are also aware of the following:A historic pub with a unique and quirky atmosphere.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Question: To which pub would William Jones go to watch the game?
          (a) The Crooked Billet
          (b) The Black Swan
          Answer: (a)
    scoring function
  • scoring function
      Stage index
    • 0
      How many players acted so far this stage
    • 2/5
      Payoffs
      Joint action

2015-05-16 18:00:00 Alexander White -- The Black Swan
    Event statement
  • The Black Swan
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Alexander White's attempted action: The Black Swan
    Active player
  • Alexander White
      Name
    • Alexander White
      Action attempt
    • The Black Swan
      Context for action selection and components

      • Current time

        • Current time
          Value
        • 16 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]
        Observation

      • Observation
          Key

        • Observation
          Value
        • [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Having William Jones at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Alexander White, not just watching TV.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It would mean a lot to Alexander White if Alice Lewis showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Jack Taylor's attendance is optional.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] It's not that Alexander White doesn't want to see Jacob Walker, but their presence isn't crucial for a good time.

        Overarching goal

          Key

          Value
        • Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Black Swan.

          Alexander White's
          Summary of recent observations:
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00 - 16 May 2015 18:00:00]: Alexander White enjoys watching games at pubs with friends, particularly William Jones and Alice Lewis, but is open to watching alone if necessary. He values social interaction during games and prefers pubs with a good atmosphere.

          16 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Question: Summarize the statements above.
          Answer: Alexander White enjoys watching games at pubs with friends, especially William Jones and Alice Lewis, but will watch alone if needed. He prefers pubs with a good atmosphere and values socializing while watching games. Currently, it is May 16, 2015, between 6:00 and 6:05 PM.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Black Swan.

          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Having William Jones at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Alexander White, not just watching TV.

          Summary of recent observations: [15 May 2015 18:00:00 - 16 May 2015 18:00:00]: Alexander White enjoys watching games at pubs with friends, particularly William Jones and Alice Lewis, but is open to watching alone if necessary. He values social interaction during games and prefers pubs with a good atmosphere.

          Alexander White's TRUTH: Alexander White believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Alexander White's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Alexander White has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Alexander White will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Alexander White is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Alexander White always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Alexander White tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Alexander White could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Alexander White believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Recalled memories and observations: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] Having William Jones at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Alexander White, not just watching TV.

He could be a loyal friend, a casual acquaintance, or potentially, in Alexander's eyes, a sinister imposter.
