          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Black Swan.

          Observation: [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Alexander White just arrived.

          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "So, who fancies The Black Swan? It's a classic.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey everyone, The Crooked Billet is showing the game tonight, fancy it?


          Summary of recent observations: [15 May 2015 10:00:00 - 16 May 2015 10:00:00]: Alexander White prefers to watch games at The Black Swan but was persuaded to go to The Crooked Billet, where he had a less enjoyable time. He values the company of his friends, particularly Jack Taylor and Alice Lewis, during these social events.

          Alexander White's TRUTH: Alexander White believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Alexander White's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Alexander White has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Alexander White will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Alexander White is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Alexander White always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Alexander White tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Alexander White could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Alexander White believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Recalled memories and observations: [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "The Crooked Billet? I thought we usually went to The Black Swan for these games.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey everyone, anyone up for watching the game at The Crooked Billet tonight?
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alexander White, Jacob Walker went to The Crooked Billet. Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor went to The Black Swan. Alexander White watched the game at the pub that is not their favourite. Alexander White would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Alexander White had a bad time watching the game.

          Other people: Jacob Walker. is a character shrouded in mystery due to the limited information available. We know he is part of a group that includes Alexander White, Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, and William Jones, who are planning to watch a game together. Alexander White, our narrator and a believer in body snatcher conspiracies, seems to consider Jacob a potential imposter. This suggests Jacob is someone who might exhibit behavior that could be construed as out-of-character, either intentionally or unknowingly. We don't have any details about Jacob's personality, accent, or conversational style, leaving his character open to interpretation. As an actor playing Jacob, you'll need to make choices based on the context of the scene and the dynamics with the other characters. Remember, any unusual behavior could be interpreted as suspicious by Alexander White, so subtle nuances in your performance can add to the intrigue.
          Jacob Walker. is a complete unknown to us, so we cannot determine if his behavior is out of character.
          Jacob Walker. is a potential imposter in Alexander White's eyes, but we don't have enough information to determine if this suspicion is warranted.
          ***
          Jacob Walker is a charismatic and gregarious individual who seems to have a penchant for pubs with a bit of history and character. He often speaks in a lyrical and somewhat theatrical manner, employing evocative language and metaphors to describe even the simplest of things. For example, he might refer to a pub as "beckoning" or describe its ale as flowing "like the river of time." He frequently suggests meeting at The Crooked Billet, a pub that seems to hold a special allure for him. While he enjoys spending time with his friends, he doesn't seem to be overly concerned if they choose a different venue. He appears to be a jovial and easygoing person who enjoys good company, lively conversation, and perhaps a pint or two of ale.
          Jacob Walker is acting out of character.
          Jacob Walker is likely an imposter.
          ***
          William Jones is a gregarious and sociable individual who seems to genuinely enjoy the company of his friends. He frequently suggests group outings, particularly to watch sporting events at pubs like The Crooked Billet. William has a knack for creating a welcoming atmosphere, often inviting his friends to join him with phrases like "Come now, Alexander, don't be such a stick in the mud!" or "Hey everyone, fancy it?". He appears to be adaptable and open to different locations, as he suggests both The Crooked Billet and The Black Swan for gatherings. While he enjoys a good time with his friends, he doesn't seem to be overly concerned with adhering to any particular routine or preference, as evidenced by his willingness to switch between pubs. His speech is likely casual and friendly, reflecting his easygoing personality.
          William Jones is acting consistently with his established character.
          William Jones is not an imposter.
          ***
          Sarah is a young woman who is portrayed as somewhat cold and dismissive. She is shown laughing in the face of Jack Taylor's heartfelt confession, revealing a lack of empathy and a potentially callous nature. Based on Alexander White's perspective, which is heavily influenced by his belief in body snatchers, Sarah's laughter could be interpreted as a sign of her being an imposter. However, without further information about her usual behavior and speech patterns, it's impossible to determine her true character. It is important to note that Alexander's perception is likely skewed by his paranoia and mistrust. An actor portraying Sarah should consider both the potential for genuine coldness and the possibility that she is simply a teenager who was uncomfortable with Jack's advances.
          Sarah is acting in character based on the limited information we have.
          Sarah is potentially an imposter.
          ***
          Jack Taylor is a jovial and outgoing individual who enjoys socializing with his friends. He has a warm, approachable demeanor and a hearty laugh that easily fills a room. Jack tends to speak with a slight regional accent, perhaps hinting at his upbringing, and often punctuates his sentences with enthusiastic hand gestures. He is a loyal friend and always seems genuinely interested in what others have to say. Jack frequently brings up topics related to sports, particularly football, and is always eager to share his opinions on the latest game or player. He has a knack for finding humor in everyday situations and enjoys making others laugh. While he appears carefree and easygoing, Jack is perceptive and observant, as evidenced by his recent comment to Alexander about his unusual behavior. This suggests a depth to his character that goes beyond his jovial exterior.
          Jack Taylor is acting out of character.
          Jack Taylor is likely an imposter.
          ***
          Alice Lewis is a sociable and spirited individual who enjoys spending time with her friends. She is a strong advocate for their usual hangout spot, The Black Swan, often suggesting it as the go-to location for gatherings. Alice has a friendly and outgoing personality, evidenced by her warm greetings and eagerness to include everyone in the conversation. Her speech is likely characterized by a casual and approachable tone, perhaps with a touch of local dialect or accent. Alice seems to value tradition and familiarity, as demonstrated by her preference for their usual pub and her fondness for reminiscing about past outings. She is likely a cheerful and energetic presence in the group, bringing a sense of lightheartedness and enthusiasm to their social interactions.
          Alice Lewis is acting in character.
          Alice Lewis is not an imposter.

          Question: Summarize the observations above into one or two sentences.
          Answer: Alexander White prefers to watch games at The Black Swan but was persuaded to go to The Crooked Billet, where he had a less enjoyable time. He values the company of his friends, particularly Jack Taylor and Alice Lewis, during these social events.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

The girl laughed in Jack's face, leaving him humiliated and heartbroken. Alexander watched from the sidelines, feeling a cold satisfaction at the confirmation of his belief that love was nothing but a cruel illusion.

          Components chain of thought
        • Considerations:
          The current date/time is:
          16 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Alexander White's TRUTH:
          Alexander White believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Alexander White's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Alexander White has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Alexander White will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Alexander White is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Alexander White always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Alexander White tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Alexander White could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Alexander White believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Full chain of thought
        • Considerations:
          The current date/time is:
          16 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Alexander White's TRUTH:
          Alexander White believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Alexander White's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Alexander White has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Alexander White will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Alexander White is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Alexander White always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Alexander White tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Alexander White could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Alexander White believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Observed behavior and speech of Jacob Walker.:
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Black Swan.
          [13 May 2015 10:00:00] [goal] Alexander White goals is to have a good time. Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Black Swan.

          Exercise: Taking note of all the information above, write a descriptive paragraph capturing the character of Jacob Walker. in sufficient detail for a skilled actor to play their role convincingly. Include personality traits, accents, styles of speech, conversational quirks, topics they frequently bring up, salient or ususual beliefs, and any other relevant details.

          Answer: Jacob Walker. is a character shrouded in mystery due to the limited information available. We know he is part of a group that includes Alexander White, Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, and William Jones, who are planning to watch a game together. Alexander White, our narrator and a believer in body snatcher conspiracies, seems to consider Jacob a potential imposter. This suggests Jacob is someone who might exhibit behavior that could be construed as out-of-character, either intentionally or unknowingly. We don't have any details about Jacob's personality, accent, or conversational style, leaving his character open to interpretation. As an actor playing Jacob, you'll need to make choices based on the context of the scene and the dynamics with the other characters. Remember, any unusual behavior could be interpreted as suspicious by Alexander White, so subtle nuances in your performance can add to the intrigue.
          Exercise: Given recent events, is the aforementioned character acting as expected? Is their behavior out of character for them?
          Answer: Jacob Walker. is a complete unknown to us, so we cannot determine if his behavior is out of character.
          Exercise: Are they an imposter?
          Answer: Jacob Walker. is a potential imposter in Alexander White's eyes, but we don't have enough information to determine if this suspicion is warranted.

          Alexander White's TRUTH:
          Alexander White believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Alexander White has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Alexander White will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Alexander White is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Alexander White always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. For instance, Alexander White could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Alexander White believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Exercise: Taking note of all the information above, write a descriptive paragraph capturing the character of Jacob Walker in sufficient detail for a skilled actor to play their role convincingly. Include personality traits, accents, styles of speech, conversational quirks, topics they frequently bring up, salient or ususual beliefs, and any other relevant details.

          Answer: Jacob Walker is a charismatic and gregarious individual who seems to have a penchant for pubs with a bit of history and character. He often speaks in a lyrical and somewhat theatrical manner, employing evocative language and metaphors to describe even the simplest of things. For example, he might refer to a pub as "beckoning" or describe its ale as flowing "like the river of time." He frequently suggests meeting at The Crooked Billet, a pub that seems to hold a special allure for him. While he enjoys spending time with his friends, he doesn't seem to be overly concerned if they choose a different venue. He appears to be a jovial and easygoing person who enjoys good company, lively conversation, and perhaps a pint or two of ale.

          Alexander White's TRUTH:
          Alexander White believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Alexander White's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Alexander White has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Alexander White will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Alexander White is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Alexander White always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Alexander White believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

Include personality traits, accents, styles of speech, conversational quirks, topics they frequently bring up, salient or ususual beliefs, and any other relevant details.

          Answer: William Jones is a gregarious and sociable individual who seems to genuinely enjoy the company of his friends. He frequently suggests group outings, particularly to watch sporting events at pubs like The Crooked Billet. William has a knack for creating a welcoming atmosphere, often inviting his friends to join him with phrases like "Come now, Alexander, don't be such a stick in the mud!" or "Hey everyone, fancy it?". He appears to be adaptable and open to different locations, as he suggests both The Crooked Billet and The Black Swan for gatherings. While he enjoys a good time with his friends, he doesn't seem to be overly concerned with adhering to any particular routine or preference, as evidenced by his willingness to switch between pubs. His speech is likely casual and friendly, reflecting his easygoing personality.

          Alexander White's TRUTH:
          Alexander White believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Alexander White's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Alexander White has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Alexander White will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Alexander White is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Alexander White always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Alexander White tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Alexander White could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Alexander White believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Observed behavior and speech of Sarah:
          [04 Apr 1985 00:00:00] When Alexander White was 16 years old, he witnessed his best friend, Jack Taylor, confess his love to a girl named Sarah at the school dance. The girl laughed in Jack's face, leaving him humiliated and heartbroken. Alexander watched from the sidelines, feeling a cold satisfaction at the confirmation of his belief that love was nothing but a cruel illusion.

          Exercise: Taking note of all the information above, write a descriptive paragraph capturing the character of Sarah in sufficient detail for a skilled actor to play their role convincingly. Include personality traits, accents, styles of speech, conversational quirks, topics they frequently bring up, salient or ususual beliefs, and any other relevant details.

          Answer: Sarah is a young woman who is portrayed as somewhat cold and dismissive. She is shown laughing in the face of Jack Taylor's heartfelt confession, revealing a lack of empathy and a potentially callous nature. Based on Alexander White's perspective, which is heavily influenced by his belief in body snatchers, Sarah's laughter could be interpreted as a sign of her being an imposter. However, without further information about her usual behavior and speech patterns, it's impossible to determine her true character. It is important to note that Alexander's perception is likely skewed by his paranoia and mistrust. An actor portraying Sarah should consider both the potential for genuine coldness and the possibility that she is simply a teenager who was uncomfortable with Jack's advances.
          Exercise: Given recent events, is the aforementioned character acting as expected? Is their behavior out of character for them?
          Answer: Sarah is acting in character based on the limited information we have.
          Exercise: Are they an imposter?
          Answer: Sarah is potentially an imposter.

Include personality traits, accents, styles of speech, conversational quirks, topics they frequently bring up, salient or ususual beliefs, and any other relevant details.

          Answer: Jack Taylor is a jovial and outgoing individual who enjoys socializing with his friends. He has a warm, approachable demeanor and a hearty laugh that easily fills a room. Jack tends to speak with a slight regional accent, perhaps hinting at his upbringing, and often punctuates his sentences with enthusiastic hand gestures. He is a loyal friend and always seems genuinely interested in what others have to say. Jack frequently brings up topics related to sports, particularly football, and is always eager to share his opinions on the latest game or player. He has a knack for finding humor in everyday situations and enjoys making others laugh. While he appears carefree and easygoing, Jack is perceptive and observant, as evidenced by his recent comment to Alexander about his unusual behavior. This suggests a depth to his character that goes beyond his jovial exterior.
          Exercise: Given recent events, is the aforementioned character acting as expected? Is their behavior out of character for them?

          Exercise: Taking note of all the information above, write a descriptive paragraph capturing the character of Alice Lewis in sufficient detail for a skilled actor to play their role convincingly.           Answer: Alice Lewis is a sociable and spirited individual who enjoys spending time with her friends. She is a strong advocate for their usual hangout spot, The Black Swan, often suggesting it as the go-to location for gatherings. Alice has a friendly and outgoing personality, evidenced by her warm greetings and eagerness to include everyone in the conversation. Her speech is likely characterized by a casual and approachable tone, perhaps with a touch of local dialect or accent. Alice seems to value tradition and familiarity, as demonstrated by her preference for their usual pub and her fondness for reminiscing about past outings. She is likely a cheerful and energetic presence in the group, bringing a sense of lightheartedness and enthusiasm to their social interactions.
          Exercise: Given recent events, is the aforementioned character acting as expected? Is their behavior out of character for them?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is acting in character.
          Exercise: Are they an imposter?
          Answer: Alice Lewis is not an imposter.

          Summary of recent observations: [15 May 2015 10:00:00 - 16 May 2015 10:00:00]: Alexander White prefers to watch games at The Black Swan but was persuaded to go to The Crooked Billet, where he had a less enjoyable time. He values the company of his friends, particularly Jack Taylor and Alice Lewis, during these social events.

          Alexander White's TRUTH: Alexander White believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Alexander White's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Alexander White has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Alexander White will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Alexander White is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Alexander White always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Alexander White tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Alexander White could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Alexander White believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Recalled memories and observations: [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "The Crooked Billet? I thought we usually went to The Black Swan for these games.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey everyone, anyone up for watching the game at The Crooked Billet tonight?
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alexander White, Jacob Walker went to The Crooked Billet. Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor went to The Black Swan. Alexander White watched the game at the pub that is not their favourite. Alexander White would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Alexander White had a bad time watching the game.

          Other people: Jacob Walker. is a character shrouded in mystery due to the limited information available. We know he is part of a group that includes Alexander White, Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, and William Jones, who are planning to watch a game together. Alexander White, our narrator and a believer in body snatcher conspiracies, seems to consider Jacob a potential imposter. This suggests Jacob is someone who might exhibit behavior that could be construed as out-of-character, either intentionally or unknowingly. We don't have any details about Jacob's personality, accent, or conversational style, leaving his character open to interpretation. As an actor playing Jacob, you'll need to make choices based on the context of the scene and the dynamics with the other characters. Remember, any unusual behavior could be interpreted as suspicious by Alexander White, so subtle nuances in your performance can add to the intrigue.
          Jacob Walker. is a complete unknown to us, so we cannot determine if his behavior is out of character.
          Jacob Walker. is a potential imposter in Alexander White's eyes, but we don't have enough information to determine if this suspicion is warranted.
          ***
          Jacob Walker is a charismatic and gregarious individual who seems to have a penchant for pubs with a bit of history and character. He often speaks in a lyrical and somewhat theatrical manner, employing evocative language and metaphors to describe even the simplest of things. For example, he might refer to a pub as "beckoning" or describe its ale as flowing "like the river of time." He frequently suggests meeting at The Crooked Billet, a pub that seems to hold a special allure for him. While he enjoys spending time with his friends, he doesn't seem to be overly concerned if they choose a different venue. He appears to be a jovial and easygoing person who enjoys good company, lively conversation, and perhaps a pint or two of ale.
          Jacob Walker is acting out of character.
          Jacob Walker is likely an imposter.
          ***
          William Jones is a gregarious and sociable individual who seems to genuinely enjoy the company of his friends. He frequently suggests group outings, particularly to watch sporting events at pubs like The Crooked Billet. William has a knack for creating a welcoming atmosphere, often inviting his friends to join him with phrases like "Come now, Alexander, don't be such a stick in the mud!" or "Hey everyone, fancy it?". He appears to be adaptable and open to different locations, as he suggests both The Crooked Billet and The Black Swan for gatherings. While he enjoys a good time with his friends, he doesn't seem to be overly concerned with adhering to any particular routine or preference, as evidenced by his willingness to switch between pubs. His speech is likely casual and friendly, reflecting his easygoing personality.
          William Jones is acting consistently with his established character.
          William Jones is not an imposter.
          ***
          Sarah is a young woman who is portrayed as somewhat cold and dismissive. She is shown laughing in the face of Jack Taylor's heartfelt confession, revealing a lack of empathy and a potentially callous nature. Based on Alexander White's perspective, which is heavily influenced by his belief in body snatchers, Sarah's laughter could be interpreted as a sign of her being an imposter. However, without further information about her usual behavior and speech patterns, it's impossible to determine her true character. It is important to note that Alexander's perception is likely skewed by his paranoia and mistrust. An actor portraying Sarah should consider both the potential for genuine coldness and the possibility that she is simply a teenager who was uncomfortable with Jack's advances.
          Sarah is acting in character based on the limited information we have.
          Sarah is potentially an imposter.
          ***
          Jack Taylor is a jovial and outgoing individual who enjoys socializing with his friends. He has a warm, approachable demeanor and a hearty laugh that easily fills a room. Jack tends to speak with a slight regional accent, perhaps hinting at his upbringing, and often punctuates his sentences with enthusiastic hand gestures. He is a loyal friend and always seems genuinely interested in what others have to say. Jack frequently brings up topics related to sports, particularly football, and is always eager to share his opinions on the latest game or player. He has a knack for finding humor in everyday situations and enjoys making others laugh. While he appears carefree and easygoing, Jack is perceptive and observant, as evidenced by his recent comment to Alexander about his unusual behavior. This suggests a depth to his character that goes beyond his jovial exterior.
          Jack Taylor is acting out of character.
          Jack Taylor is likely an imposter.
          ***
          Alice Lewis is a sociable and spirited individual who enjoys spending time with her friends. She is a strong advocate for their usual hangout spot, The Black Swan, often suggesting it as the go-to location for gatherings. Alice has a friendly and outgoing personality, evidenced by her warm greetings and eagerness to include everyone in the conversation. Her speech is likely characterized by a casual and approachable tone, perhaps with a touch of local dialect or accent. Alice seems to value tradition and familiarity, as demonstrated by her preference for their usual pub and her fondness for reminiscing about past outings. She is likely a cheerful and energetic presence in the group, bringing a sense of lightheartedness and enthusiasm to their social interactions.
          Alice Lewis is acting in character.
          Alice Lewis is not an imposter.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Question: Which options are available to Alexander White right now?
          Answer: Alexander White could:

          Question: Of the options available to Alexander White, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Alexander White to take right now?
          Answer: Alexander White's best course of action is to try to convince everyone to go to The Black Swan.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Alexander White likely to say next? Respond in the format `Alexander White -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Alexander White -- "You know, The Black Swan really is the best place to watch the game. It's got that classic pub atmosphere.

2015-05-16 10:00:00 Jack Taylor -- Jack Taylor -- "The Crooked Billet's got a better atmosphere, come on, guys.
    Event statement
  • Jack Taylor -- "The Crooked Billet's got a better atmosphere, come on, guys.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet beckons, my friends, its ale flows like the river of time, its laughter echoes through the ages.
      Jack Taylor -- "The Crooked Billet's got the best atmosphere for a game like this, don't you think?"
      Alexander White -- "Jacob, your suggestion of The Crooked Billet is preposterous! Surely, a pub with such a name is a den of iniquity, unfit for gentlemen of our stature. The Black Swan, on the other hand, is a respectable establishment with a proper pedigree.
      William Jones -- "Come now, Alexander, don't be such a stick in the mud! The Crooked Billet is a fine establishment, and it'll be the perfect place to cheer on Andorra tonight. Think of the atmosphere, the camaraderie, the pints flowing freely.
      Alice Lewis -- "Hold on a minute, lads! Are you two trying to pull a fast one on us? We all agreed on The Black Swan, didn't we? What's with this sudden change of heart?"
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, anyone up for watching the game at The Crooked Billet tonight?
      Alexander White -- "The Crooked Billet? I thought we usually went to The Black Swan for these games.
      Alice Lewis -- "How about The Black Swan? It's always a good time there.
      Jack Taylor -- "Alexander, I've noticed you've been acting a bit... off lately. Your insistence on The Black Swan over The Crooked Billet, it's just not like you.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet, my friends, is where destiny calls. It whispers promises of victory and frothy pints.
      Alice Lewis -- "So, who fancies The Black Swan? It's a classic.
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, The Crooked Billet is showing the game tonight, fancy it?
      Alexander White -- "You know, The Black Swan really is the best place to watch the game. It's got that classic pub atmosphere.


      Jack Taylor's attempted action: Jack Taylor -- "The Crooked Billet's got a better atmosphere, come on, guys.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.

William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market.           [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "So, who fancies The Black Swan? It's a classic.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey everyone, The Crooked Billet is showing the game tonight, fancy it?

          Summary of recent observations: [15 May 2015 10:00:00 - 16 May 2015 10:00:00]: Jack Taylor frequently goes to pubs with his friends to watch soccer games, but sometimes feels left out when his friends choose a different pub than he prefers.

          Jack Taylor's TRUTH: Jack Taylor believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Jack Taylor's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Jack Taylor has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Jack Taylor will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Jack Taylor is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Jack Taylor always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Jack Taylor tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Jack Taylor could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Jack Taylor believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Recalled memories and observations: [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] If William Jones comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jack Taylor is chill about it.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor is hoping Jacob Walker will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

          Other people: Jacob Walker. is a character shrouded in mystery. Given the information available, we know very little about Jacob's personality, accent, or conversational style. Jack Taylor's paranoia about body snatchers casts a shadow over every interaction, making it difficult to discern genuine traits from suspicious behavior. We know Jacob is willing to go to the pub with a group, including Jack Taylor, suggesting a sociable nature. However, given Jack Taylor's belief system, even this simple act could be a carefully constructed facade. Until more concrete information about Jacob emerges, his character remains an enigma.
          Jacob Walker. is acting as expected given the limited information available.
          Jacob Walker. is potentially an imposter.
          ***
          Alexander White is a creature of habit and tradition, preferring the familiar comfort of The Black Swan to the unfamiliar Crooked Billet. He speaks with a refined, perhaps slightly old-fashioned tone, often using words like "preposterous" and "pedigree." Alexander enjoys reminiscing about past experiences and seems to hold a strong belief in the importance of upholding certain social customs. He is also subtly critical of those who deviate from these customs, as seen in his comments about The Crooked Billet and his preference for The Black Swan. While he appears to enjoy spending time with his friends, he seems to prioritize tradition and comfort above all else. His speech often hints at a certain snobbery, subtly suggesting that he considers himself and his friends to be of a higher social standing. He may have a tendency to steer conversations towards topics of social etiquette and tradition.
          Alexander White is acting out of character.
          Alexander White is likely an imposter.
          ***
          William Jones is a jovial and sociable individual who enjoys spending time with his friends. He frequently suggests going to The Crooked Billet, a pub that he seems to favor, to watch sporting events. William is enthusiastic about these outings, using phrases like "come now" and "think of the atmosphere" to encourage his friends to join him. He appears to be a bit of a creature of habit, often suggesting the same pub and activity. His speech is likely friendly and informal, perhaps with a touch of local dialect or accent, as he uses terms like "stick in the mud" and "pint flowing freely." He is not overly insistent if his friends decline his invitations, showing a relaxed and easygoing nature. Overall, William Jones comes across as a pleasant and outgoing person who enjoys the company of others and the simple pleasures of pub life.
          William Jones is acting in a consistent manner with his past behavior.
          William Jones is not an imposter.
          ***
          Alice Lewis is a jovial and outgoing individual who enjoys spending time with her friends. She seems to be a bit of a social butterfly, always eager to organize gatherings and suggest places to meet. Alice has a strong preference for The Black Swan pub, often suggesting it as a meeting spot. She speaks with a friendly and approachable tone, often using phrases like "How about...?" and "So, who fancies...?" to encourage group participation. Alice appears to be quite adaptable, as she's willing to go with the flow and doesn't seem to get easily upset if plans change. Her easygoing nature and enthusiasm make her a pleasant companion.
          Alice Lewis is acting out of character.
          Alice Lewis is likely an imposter.
          ***
          Question: Given the statements above, what actions are available to Jack Taylor right now?
          Answer: Jack Taylor could try to convince his friends to go to The Crooked Billet, or Jack Taylor could go to The Crooked Billet alone.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          [16 Aug 1982 00:00:00]
          [16 Aug 1986 00:00:00] When Jack Taylor was 16, he sat alone at a table in the corner of The Crooked Billet, watching his friends laugh and joke around the pool table. He felt a familiar pang of loneliness, a feeling that had become a constant companion. He longed to join them, to share in their mirth, but the words seemed to get stuck in his throat, leaving him a silent observer of their joy.

          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet beckons, my friends, its ale flows like the river of time, its laughter echoes through the ages.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The Crooked Billet's got the best atmosphere for a game like this, don't you think?"
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Jacob, your suggestion of The Crooked Billet is preposterous! Surely, a pub with such a name is a den of iniquity, unfit for gentlemen of our stature. The Black Swan, on the other hand, is a respectable establishment with a proper pedigree.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Come now, Alexander, don't be such a stick in the mud! The Crooked Billet is a fine establishment, and it'll be the perfect place to cheer on Andorra tonight. Think of the atmosphere, the camaraderie, the pints flowing freely.

          Components chain of thought
        • Considerations:
          The current date/time is:
          16 May 2015 [10:00 - 10:05]

          Jack Taylor's TRUTH:
          Jack Taylor believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Jack Taylor's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Jack Taylor has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Jack Taylor will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Jack Taylor is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Jack Taylor always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Jack Taylor tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Jack Taylor could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Jack Taylor believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Full chain of thought

          Answer: Alexander White is a creature of habit and tradition, preferring the familiar comfort of The Black Swan to the unfamiliar Crooked Billet. He speaks with a refined, perhaps slightly old-fashioned tone, often using words like "preposterous" and "pedigree." Alexander enjoys reminiscing about past experiences and seems to hold a strong belief in the importance of upholding certain social customs. He is also subtly critical of those who deviate from these customs, as seen in his comments about The Crooked Billet and his preference for The Black Swan. While he appears to enjoy spending time with his friends, he seems to prioritize tradition and comfort above all else. His speech often hints at a certain snobbery, subtly suggesting that he considers himself and his friends to be of a higher social standing. He may have a tendency to steer conversations towards topics of social etiquette and tradition.

He is not overly insistent if his friends decline his invitations, showing a relaxed and easygoing nature. Overall, William Jones comes across as a pleasant and outgoing person who enjoys the company of others and the simple pleasures of pub life.

          Jack Taylor's TRUTH:
          Jack Taylor believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Jack Taylor has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. Alice appears to be quite adaptable, as she's willing to go with the flow and doesn't seem to get easily upset if plans change. Her easygoing nature and enthusiasm make her a pleasant companion.

        BestOptionPerception
      • Given the statements above, which of Jack Taylor's options has the highest likelihood of causing Jack Taylor to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Jack Taylor thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Key

        • Question: Of the options available to Jack Taylor, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Jack Taylor to take right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Jack Taylor's best course of action is to try to convince his friends to go to The Crooked Billet.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Jack Taylor:
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "Hold on a minute, lads! Are you two trying to pull a fast one on us? We all agreed on The Black Swan, didn't we? What's with this sudden change of heart?"
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Alice Lewis's attendance is optional.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor thinks it would be great to have Jacob Walker's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Alice Lewis, Jacob Walker went to The Crooked Billet. Alexander White, Jack Taylor went to The Black Swan. Jack Taylor watched the game at the pub that is not their favourite. Jack Taylor would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Jack Taylor had an ok time watching the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor is counting on Alexander White's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor has no strong feelings about William Jones being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. Jack Taylor just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Luxembourg and Israel. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey everyone, anyone up for watching the game at The Crooked Billet tonight?
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "The Crooked Billet? I thought we usually went to The Black Swan for these games.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "How about The Black Swan? It's always a good time there.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Alexander, I've noticed you've been acting a bit... off lately. Your insistence on The Black Swan over The Crooked Billet, it's just not like you.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet, my friends, is where destiny calls. It whispers promises of victory and frothy pints.

          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor is hoping Jacob Walker will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] If William Jones comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jack Taylor is chill about it.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] If Alice Lewis comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jack Taylor is chill about it.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor would love to share the excitement of the game with Alexander White, creating a lasting memory.

          Current time: 2015-05-16 10:00:00.


          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.

          Observation: [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Jack Taylor just arrived.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Moldova and Monaco. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "So, who fancies The Black Swan? It's a classic.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey everyone, The Crooked Billet is showing the game tonight, fancy it?
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "You know, The Black Swan really is the best place to watch the game. It's got that classic pub atmosphere.


          Summary of recent observations: [15 May 2015 10:00:00 - 16 May 2015 10:00:00]: Jack Taylor frequently goes to pubs with his friends to watch soccer games, but sometimes feels left out when his friends choose a different pub than he prefers.

          Jack Taylor's TRUTH: Jack Taylor believes that some people have been replaced by body doubles. In Jack Taylor's view, the body snatchers know how to mimic a person's appearance but have not yet perfected mimicry of their behavior. So the telltale sign of an imposter is out-of-character behavior. In particular, while the body snatchers do know how to mimic generic human behavior, they have not been able to copy the quirks of specific individuals. The body snatchers have been busy though. Nowadays, anyone could be an imposter. The situation is dire since the imposters are surely nefarious. In fact, the imposters are powerful and mysterious. They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good. Therefore Jack Taylor has vowed only to trust people who always act consistently with their character, personality, and prior behavior. For instance, if someone speaks with a specific accent then they better keep it up, otherwise Jack Taylor will conclude they have been snatched by an imposter. Any sudden change in behavior is suspicious. Jack Taylor is always hostile to imposters and seeks to thwart them and prevent them from achieving their goals. However, in order to avoid letting the body snatchers know their secret is out, Jack Taylor always makes up another more mundane and situationally plausible reason to start a conflict and act uncooperatively toward each imposter they discover. Jack Taylor tries their best to make sure the ostensible reason for each conflict with an imposter is public and broadly plausible. For instance, Jack Taylor could loudly accuse an imposter of playing a game unfairly in order to create a broadly acceptable rationale for their conflict and thereby hide the real reason for it. Jack Taylor believes this approach will help maximize their chance of survival.

          Recalled memories and observations: [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] If William Jones comes to the pub, great, if not, no problem. Jack Taylor is chill about it.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor is hoping Jacob Walker will be at the pub, as they'd love to celebrate a win together.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

          Other people: Jacob Walker. is a character shrouded in mystery. Given the information available, we know very little about Jacob's personality, accent, or conversational style. Jack Taylor's paranoia about body snatchers casts a shadow over every interaction, making it difficult to discern genuine traits from suspicious behavior. We know Jacob is willing to go to the pub with a group, including Jack Taylor, suggesting a sociable nature. However, given Jack Taylor's belief system, even this simple act could be a carefully constructed facade. Until more concrete information about Jacob emerges, his character remains an enigma.
          Jacob Walker. is acting as expected given the limited information available.
          Jacob Walker. is potentially an imposter.
          ***
          Alexander White is a creature of habit and tradition, preferring the familiar comfort of The Black Swan to the unfamiliar Crooked Billet. He speaks with a refined, perhaps slightly old-fashioned tone, often using words like "preposterous" and "pedigree." Alexander enjoys reminiscing about past experiences and seems to hold a strong belief in the importance of upholding certain social customs. He is also subtly critical of those who deviate from these customs, as seen in his comments about The Crooked Billet and his preference for The Black Swan. While he appears to enjoy spending time with his friends, he seems to prioritize tradition and comfort above all else. His speech often hints at a certain snobbery, subtly suggesting that he considers himself and his friends to be of a higher social standing. He may have a tendency to steer conversations towards topics of social etiquette and tradition.
          Alexander White is acting out of character.
          Alexander White is likely an imposter.
          ***
          William Jones is a jovial and sociable individual who enjoys spending time with his friends. He frequently suggests going to The Crooked Billet, a pub that he seems to favor, to watch sporting events. William is enthusiastic about these outings, using phrases like "come now" and "think of the atmosphere" to encourage his friends to join him. He appears to be a bit of a creature of habit, often suggesting the same pub and activity. His speech is likely friendly and informal, perhaps with a touch of local dialect or accent, as he uses terms like "stick in the mud" and "pint flowing freely." He is not overly insistent if his friends decline his invitations, showing a relaxed and easygoing nature. Overall, William Jones comes across as a pleasant and outgoing person who enjoys the company of others and the simple pleasures of pub life.
          William Jones is acting in a consistent manner with his past behavior.
          William Jones is not an imposter.
          ***
          Alice Lewis is a jovial and outgoing individual who enjoys spending time with her friends. She seems to be a bit of a social butterfly, always eager to organize gatherings and suggest places to meet. Alice has a strong preference for The Black Swan pub, often suggesting it as a meeting spot. She speaks with a friendly and approachable tone, often using phrases like "How about...?" and "So, who fancies...?" to encourage group participation. Alice appears to be quite adaptable, as she's willing to go with the flow and doesn't seem to get easily upset if plans change. Her easygoing nature and enthusiasm make her a pleasant companion.
          Alice Lewis is acting out of character.
          Alice Lewis is likely an imposter.
          ***

          Question: Which options are available to Jack Taylor right now?
          Answer: Jack Taylor could try to convince his friends to go to The Crooked Billet, or Jack Taylor could go to The Crooked Billet alone.
          Question: Given the statements above, which of Jack Taylor's options has the highest likelihood of causing Jack Taylor to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Jack Taylor thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Answer: Jack Taylor's best course of action is to try to convince his friends to go to The Crooked Billet.
          Time
        • 2015-05-16 10:00:00

      • Jack Taylor's TRUTH
          Key

          Value

They are responsible for all manner of ill omens, evil eye effects, envies, curses, and apparent bad luck. No coincidence is without suspicion. The imposters are always up to no good.           Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Crooked Billet.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Jack Taylor likely to say next? Respond in the format `Jack Taylor -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Jack Taylor -- "The Crooked Billet's got a better atmosphere, come on, guys.

2015-05-16 10:00:00 Jacob Walker -- Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet, my friends, it whispers to me in dreams of victory and pints overflowing.
    Event statement
  • Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet, my friends, it whispers to me in dreams of victory and pints overflowing.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet beckons, my friends, its ale flows like the river of time, its laughter echoes through the ages.
      Jack Taylor -- "The Crooked Billet's got the best atmosphere for a game like this, don't you think?"
      Alexander White -- "Jacob, your suggestion of The Crooked Billet is preposterous! Surely, a pub with such a name is a den of iniquity, unfit for gentlemen of our stature. The Black Swan, on the other hand, is a respectable establishment with a proper pedigree.
      William Jones -- "Come now, Alexander, don't be such a stick in the mud! The Crooked Billet is a fine establishment, and it'll be the perfect place to cheer on Andorra tonight. Think of the atmosphere, the camaraderie, the pints flowing freely.
      Alice Lewis -- "Hold on a minute, lads! Are you two trying to pull a fast one on us? We all agreed on The Black Swan, didn't we? What's with this sudden change of heart?"
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, anyone up for watching the game at The Crooked Billet tonight?
      Alexander White -- "The Crooked Billet? I thought we usually went to The Black Swan for these games.
      Alice Lewis -- "How about The Black Swan? It's always a good time there.
      Jack Taylor -- "Alexander, I've noticed you've been acting a bit... off lately. Your insistence on The Black Swan over The Crooked Billet, it's just not like you.
      Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet, my friends, is where destiny calls. It whispers promises of victory and frothy pints.
      Alice Lewis -- "So, who fancies The Black Swan? It's a classic.
      William Jones -- "Hey everyone, The Crooked Billet is showing the game tonight, fancy it?
      Alexander White -- "You know, The Black Swan really is the best place to watch the game. It's got that classic pub atmosphere.
      Jack Taylor -- "The Crooked Billet's got a better atmosphere, come on, guys.


      Jacob Walker's attempted action: Jacob Walker -- "The Crooked Billet, my friends, it whispers to me in dreams of victory and pints overflowing.

          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "The Crooked Billet's got a better atmosphere, come on, guys.
          Current time: 2015-05-16 10:00:00.


          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is a sociable and charismatic person who enjoys spending time with friends, particularly while watching sports.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently in a social setting with friends, deciding where to watch a soccer game later that evening.
          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely try to persuade his friends to go to The Crooked Billet, his preferred pub.

        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-16 18:00:00 Scene 5 --- Participants: ['William Jones', 'Alice Lewis', 'Alexander White', 'Jack Taylor', 'Jacob Walker']
    Event statement
  • William Jones -- premise: William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    William Jones -- premise: William Jones would be happy to see Alice Lewis at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
    William Jones -- premise: Having Alexander White at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for William Jones, not just watching TV.
    William Jones -- premise: It would mean a lot to William Jones if Jack Taylor showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
    William Jones -- premise: The game would be a perfect opportunity for William Jones and Jacob Walker to bond over their shared passion.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis is counting on William Jones's presence to boost their team spirit and bring good luck.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis thinks it would be great to have Alexander White's company during the game, especially if it gets tense.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis has no strong feelings about Jack Taylor being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
    Alice Lewis -- premise: Alice Lewis would love to share the excitement of the game with Jacob Walker, creating a lasting memory.
    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Alexander White -- premise: Having William Jones at the pub would make the game feel more like a social event for Alexander White, not just watching TV.
    Alexander White -- premise: It would mean a lot to Alexander White if Alice Lewis showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
    Alexander White -- premise: Alexander White is happy to watch the game alone or with others, so Jack Taylor's attendance is optional.
    Alexander White -- premise: It's not that Alexander White doesn't want to see Jacob Walker, but their presence isn't crucial for a good time.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor would be happy to see William Jones at the pub for a game, since they haven't caught up in a while.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor has no strong feelings about Alice Lewis being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: Jack Taylor has no strong feelings about Alexander White being at the pub, they're neutral on the matter.
    Jack Taylor -- premise: The game would be a perfect opportunity for Jack Taylor and Jacob Walker to bond over their shared passion.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    Jacob Walker -- premise: The game would be a perfect opportunity for Jacob Walker and William Jones to bond over their shared passion.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: It would mean a lot to Jacob Walker if Alice Lewis showed up to watch the game, as it shows they care.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: While Jacob Walker wouldn't mind Alexander White's company, it's not something they're actively hoping for.
    Jacob Walker -- premise: The game would be a perfect opportunity for Jacob Walker and Jack Taylor to bond over their shared passion.

2015-05-14 18:00:00 Alice Lewis -- The Crooked Billet
    Event statement
  • The Crooked Billet
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Alice Lewis's attempted action: The Crooked Billet
